title: Venezuela Aviation Ban Turns Airspace Into Political Leverage - Travel Radar
description:
Several carriers suspended flights in response, triggering Venezuela’s National Institute of Civil Aviation (INAC) to revoke their operating permits, a decisive step in asserting control over Venezuela airspace.
Venezuela’s government accused the airlines of joining “actions of state terrorism promoted by the United States” President Nicolás Maduro framed the Venezuela aviation ban as a demonstration of sovereignty.
Venezuela-US mounting Tensions The airline ban comes amid growing U.S.-Venezuela tensions.
These actions prompted the FAA advisory, which in turn sparked the Venezuela aviation ban and broader Venezuela airline restrictions 2025.
While both the U.S. and Venezuela have indicated willingness to maintain dialogue, the Venezuela aviation ban shows how geopolitical tensions continue to spill into global airspace, intersecting with diplomacy, security, and state strategy.
text:
Venezuela has banned six international airlines, including carriers from Spain and Turkey, following a U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) advisory warning of “worsening security situation and heightened military activity in and around Venezuela,” including GPS interference and the deployment of air-defence systems. Several carriers suspended flights in response, triggering Venezuela’s National Institute of Civil Aviation (INAC) to revoke their operating permits, a decisive step in asserting control over Venezuela airspace.

Airspace Control as a Strategic Tool

On November 21, 2025, the U.S. FAA issued a Notice to Airmen (NOTAM) warning of a “potentially hazardous situation” in Venezuelan airspace, citing increased military readiness, GPS interference, and U.S. deployments in the Caribbean targeting alleged drug trafficking. In response, several international carriers including Iberia, TAP Air Portugal, Turkish Airlines, Avianca, LATAM, and Gol temporarily suspended flights to Caracas (more details here).

Venezuela’s National Institute of Civil Aviation (INAC) responded by issuing a 48-hour ultimatum for the carriers to resume service. When the deadline passed without the airlines complying, INAC revoked their operating rights. Venezuela’s government accused the airlines of joining “actions of state terrorism promoted by the United States”

President Nicolás Maduro framed the Venezuela aviation ban as a demonstration of sovereignty. In a televised address, he declared Venezuela “invincible,” signalling to both domestic and international audiences that foreign carriers would not dictate operations within Venezuelan airspace. The government’s measures reflect how aviation is used as political leverage in ongoing negotiations with the U.S.

The move follows other actions in 2025, including public references to a “prolonged resistance” strategy. By grounding airlines and controlling flight routes, Venezuela ensures that Venezuela airline restrictions 2025 directly influence international mobility while amplifying its political stance.

Venezuela-US mounting Tensions

The airline ban comes amid growing U.S.-Venezuela tensions. The U.S. has increased its military presence in the Caribbean, assembling its largest military presence in the Caribbean since the 1989 invasion of Panama. This build-up, part of “Operation Southern Spear,” began in August 2025 with the deployment of the USS Iwo Jima Amphibious Ready Group, and was bolstered in November by the arrival of the USS Gerald R. Ford carrier strike group.

Sanctions and legal measures remain in place: U.S. indictments of senior Venezuelan officials, including Maduro, and a $50 million bounty on the president, continue to escalate pressures. These actions prompted the FAA advisory, which in turn sparked the Venezuela aviation ban and broader Venezuela airline restrictions 2025.

Aviation at the Center of the Standoff

After major international airlines voluntarily suspended flights to Venezuela following a U.S. safety warning, Venezuela retaliated by revoking their operating permits, demonstrating how aviation is used as a tool of political leverage. The decisions highlight the key strategic power commercial aviation can have in international diplomacy: controlling flight operations can send messages and enforce pressure without deploying hard military power.

For now, several international routes to Caracas remain suspended, with no timeline for reinstatement. While both the U.S. and Venezuela have indicated willingness to maintain dialogue, the Venezuela aviation ban shows how geopolitical tensions continue to spill into global airspace, intersecting with diplomacy, security, and state strategy.

title: Airlines warn of flight delays after Airbus orders urgent software fix - greaterkashmir
description:
New Delhi, Nov 29: Airlines across the world have warned of delays and possible disruptions after Airbus issued an urgent directive calling for immediate modifications to thousands of its aircraft.
The move follows as reported by BBC, the discovery that intense solar radiation could corrupt data linked to flight control systems, a risk that Airbus says requires a swift software update.
According to the BBC, more airlines are now reporting potential disruptions as Airbus begins recalling affected aircraft for the update.
Other airlines have also responded: American Airlines said about 340 of its planes are affected and warned of “some operational delays” but expects most updates to be completed today or tomorrow.
Airbus says the majority of affected aircraft only require a software installation, normally a three-hour process.
text:
New Delhi, Nov 29: Airlines across the world have warned of delays and possible disruptions after Airbus issued an urgent directive calling for immediate modifications to thousands of its aircraft. The move follows as reported by BBC, the discovery that intense solar radiation could corrupt data linked to flight control systems, a risk that Airbus says requires a swift software update.

According to the BBC, more airlines are now reporting potential disruptions as Airbus begins recalling affected aircraft for the update. The recall applies to roughly 6,000 planes globally, nearly half of Airbus’s fleet, making it, as BBC’s notes, “a very unusual situation”.

Air India & Indico issue travel advisories

Air India and IndiGo have issued warnings of longer turnaround times and possible delays, according to The Mint. The publication reported that both airlines have advised passengers to check flight status before heading to the airport, noting that operations may be affected as Airbus’s directive is implemented. “The software/hardware realignment on part of our fleet will lead to delayed operations,” Air India said in a post on X, adding that it regretted any inconvenience caused to passengers.

Other airlines have also responded: American Airlines said about 340 of its planes are affected and warned of “some operational delays” but expects most updates to be completed today or tomorrow. Delta Airlines said it will comply with Airbus’s instruction and expects the impact to be “limited”. London Heathrow said its operations remain unaffected, while Gatwick Airport expects some disruption.

Airbus says the majority of affected aircraft only require a software installation, normally a three-hour process. But around 900 older planes will need computer hardware replaced and will not be allowed to carry passengers until that is done. Availability of parts remains a concern, and it is currently unclear whether replacements can be sourced in time.

BBC reported that the software directive primarily targets the A320 family, which Airbus describes as the “aircraft family of choice for airlines around the world.” These planes can fly up to 4,700 nautical miles (8,700 km) and seat between 120 and 244 passengers. The A320 also flies using 50% sustainable aviation fuel, a figure Airbus hopes to raise to 100% by 2030.

The aircraft features advanced turbofan engines that offer 20% lower fuel burn compared with previous generations, one reason why it remains central to commercial fleets worldwide. With thousands of aircraft grounded or awaiting updates, passengers across continents have been urged to monitor flight schedules and allow extra time at airports.

title: Central Asia and the EU Discuss Tourism Cooperation - Uzdaily
description:
Tashkent, Uzbekistan (UzDaily.com) — On 28 November 2025, the first Tourism Forum “Central Asia – European Union” was held in Tashkent as part of International Tourism Week.
The event brought together heads of tourism authorities from Central Asian countries and the European Union, as well as over 150 industry specialists and representatives of international delegations.
The forum focused on key issues for developing the tourism sector, expanding cooperation, and strengthening business ties between the region and the EU.
During panel sessions, participants exchanged experiences in applying digital technologies in tourism, preserving cultural heritage, and promoting the tourist potential of Central Asia.
The forum served as an important platform to showcase the region’s tourism opportunities, create new international contacts, and strengthen cooperation between Central Asian countries and the EU.
text:
Tashkent, Uzbekistan (UzDaily.com) — On 28 November 2025, the first Tourism Forum “Central Asia – European Union” was held in Tashkent as part of International Tourism Week.

The event brought together heads of tourism authorities from Central Asian countries and the European Union, as well as over 150 industry specialists and representatives of international delegations.

The forum focused on key issues for developing the tourism sector, expanding cooperation, and strengthening business ties between the region and the EU.

During panel sessions, participants exchanged experiences in applying digital technologies in tourism, preserving cultural heritage, and promoting the tourist potential of Central Asia.

Special attention was given to fostering dialogue between the region and the European Union and exploring joint opportunities to enhance international collaboration.

The forum served as an important platform to showcase the region’s tourism opportunities, create new international contacts, and strengthen cooperation between Central Asian countries and the EU.

title: Airlines warn of flight delays after Airbus orders urgent software fix - Gulistan News Tv
description:
New Delhi, Nov 29: Airlines worldwide are cautioning passengers about possible delays after Airbus issued an urgent directive for immediate software modifications across thousands of its aircraft.
The directive covers nearly 6,000 aircraft, almost half of Airbus’s global fleet, making it an unusual and large-scale recall.
More airlines have begun reporting likely disruptions as affected jets are pulled from service for updates.
Both airlines urged passengers to check their flight status before leaving for the airport.
With thousands of aircraft awaiting updates, travellers are being advised to keep a close watch on schedules and plan additional time at airports.
text:
New Delhi, Nov 29: Airlines worldwide are cautioning passengers about possible delays after Airbus issued an urgent directive for immediate software modifications across thousands of its aircraft. The move follows the discovery that intense solar radiation could interfere with data used by flight control systems, prompting a rapid response from the manufacturer.

The directive covers nearly 6,000 aircraft, almost half of Airbus’s global fleet, making it an unusual and large-scale recall. More airlines have begun reporting likely disruptions as affected jets are pulled from service for updates.

Indian carriers issue advisories

Air India and IndiGo have warned of longer turnaround times and possible delays. Both airlines urged passengers to check their flight status before leaving for the airport. Air India said the software and hardware adjustments required for part of its fleet will slow operations and apologised for the inconvenience.

Other global carriers are taking similar steps. American Airlines said about 340 of its planes are affected and expects “some operational delays,” though most updates should be wrapped up within a day or two. Delta Airlines expects only limited impact. London Heathrow reported normal operations, while Gatwick Airport flagged potential disruption.

Most aircraft will need only a software installation, a process that generally takes about three hours. Older jets — roughly 900 of them — require a hardware replacement and cannot carry passengers until that work is completed. The availability of parts remains uncertain, raising concerns about how long some planes may remain grounded.

The directive mainly affects the A320 family, a core part of many global fleets. These aircraft typically carry between 120 and 244 passengers and can fly up to 4,700 nautical miles. They are also certified to run on 50 percent sustainable aviation fuel, with plans to eventually reach full compatibility.

With thousands of aircraft awaiting updates, travellers are being advised to keep a close watch on schedules and plan additional time at airports.

title: Jet Aviation launches operations at KOPF
description:
Jet Aviation has launched initial operations at its new FBO at Miami-Opa Locka Executive Airport (KOPF) in Florida.
The new facility is Jet Aviation’s 12th FBO in the US, joining a global network of some 30 FBOs worldwide.
The company broke ground on the new facility in October 2024, with full completion scheduled for mid-2026.
Initial operations launched Nov. 10, 2025, include a 540,000-square-foot ramp, two new taxiway connections into the airport system, fueling with Jet-A, 100LL, and sustainable aviation fuel, and drive-on access to the ramp via a private entrance, according to company officials.
Upon completion next year, the newly built facility will also feature an 8,500-square-foot FBO building with a private entrance on the west side of the airfield, electric vehicle charging systems, LED lighting and photovoltaic panels, on-site Customs and Border Protection, and 40,000 square feet of hangar space available for nightly transient parking, company officials added.
text:

The new facility is Jet Aviation’s 12th FBO in the US, joining a global network of some 30 FBOs worldwide.

Initial operations launched Nov. 10, 2025, include a 540,000-square-foot ramp, two new taxiway connections into the airport system, fueling with Jet-A, 100LL, and sustainable aviation fuel, and drive-on access to the ramp via a private entrance, according to company officials.

Upon completion next year, the newly built facility will also feature an 8,500-square-foot FBO building with a private entrance on the west side of the airfield, electric vehicle charging systems, LED lighting and photovoltaic panels, on-site Customs and Border Protection, and 40,000 square feet of hangar space available for nightly transient parking, company officials added.

title: Tallow Market | Global Market Analysis Report - 2035 - FactMR
description:
Tallow Market Forecast and Outlook 2025 to 2035 The global tallow market is set to grow from USD 9.6 billion in 2025 to USD 19.7 billion by 2035, adding USD 10.1 billion in new revenue and advancing at a CAGR of 7.5%.
What Makes Cattle/Bovine Command the Largest Share in the Tallow Market?
Europe Market Split by Country The European tallow market is projected to grow from USD 2.1 billion in 2025 to USD 3.7 billion by 2035, representing 22.0% of the global market in 2025 and expanding to 18.8% by 2035.

Tallow Market by Segments
text:
Tallow Market Forecast and Outlook 2025 to 2035

The global tallow market is set to grow from USD 9.6 billion in 2025 to USD 19.7 billion by 2035, adding USD 10.1 billion in new revenue and advancing at a CAGR of 7.5%. Growth is driven by escalating demand for sustainable biofuel feedstock across renewable energy sectors, expanding oleochemical manufacturing infrastructure in industrial markets, and accelerating food processing requirements among manufacturing organizations seeking versatile animal fat solutions.

Tallow technologies are increasingly recognized as essential raw materials for industrial practitioners, offering superior energy density capabilities, cost-effective processing assurance, and comprehensive application versatility characteristics compared to alternative vegetable oil feedstock approaches.

Quick Stats for Tallow Market

Tallow Market Value (2025): USD 9.6 billion

Tallow Market Forecast Value (2035): USD 19.7 billion

Tallow Market Forecast CAGR: 7.5%

Leading Animal Source in Tallow Market: Cattle/Bovine (46.3%)

Key Growth Regions in Tallow Market: Asia Pacific, North America, and Middle East & Africa

Top Players in Tallow Market: Darling Ingredients, SARIA SE & Co. KG, Cargill, Ajinomoto Co., Inc., Vantage Specialty Chemicals

Cattle/bovine tallow formulations dominate the market, favored in food processing and industrial environments for their established availability properties, providing consistent quality mechanisms, reliable supply capabilities, and processing acceptance across diverse manufacturing applications and industry demographics.

Food & Beverage applications remain fundamental in tallow utilization protocols where culinary requirements and nutritional specifications match operational standards and product quality confidence expectations. B2B distribution channels are advancing among commercial categories as specialized rendering facility networks expand and bulk supply infrastructure increases accessibility in production-convenient locations with efficient logistics structures.

Geographic concentration demonstrates dynamic growth patterns with India and South Africa leading expansion, supported by rising livestock processing capacity, industrial oleochemical consciousness expansion among manufacturing populations, and rendering infrastructure establishment programs in agricultural centers.

USA, China, Brazil, Germany, and UAE demonstrate robust development through established rendering industry ecosystems, regulatory framework maturity for animal by-products, and standardized acceptance of tallow utilization procedures. Competitive advantage is consolidating around fatty acid composition profiles, rendering quality documentation, feedstock traceability systems, and integrated oleochemical portfolios rather than commodity tallow supplies alone.

The first half of the decade will witness the market climbing from USD 9.6 billion to approximately USD 13.7 billion, adding USD 4.1 billion in value, which constitutes 41% of the total forecast growth period. This phase will be characterized by the continued dominance of bovine tallow methodologies in food processing settings, combined with accelerating adoption of biodiesel feedstock applications in renewable energy manufacturing where sustainability credentials and cost-effectiveness create favorable production economics outcomes.

The latter half will witness sustained expansion from USD 13.7 billion to USD 19.7 billion, representing an addition of USD 6.0 billion or 59% of the decade's growth, defined by broadening acceptance of specialty oleochemical protocols and integration of sustainable chemistry platforms across mainstream industrial manufacturing facilities.

Where revenue comes from - Now Vs Next (industry-level view)

Period Primary Revenue Buckets Share Notes Today Cattle/Bovine 46.3% Livestock dominance Food & Beverage 41.8% Culinary applications B2B Distribution 52.1% Industrial channel Sheep/Goat 27.6% Alternative source Animal/Pet Feed 26.4% Nutrition supplement Future (3-5 yrs) Biodiesel Feedstock 45-51% Renewable energy expansion Oleochemical Applications 42-48% Industrial chemistry growth Specialty Fatty Acids 38-44% High-value derivatives Sustainable Aviation Fuel 32-38% Advanced biofuel adoption Personal Care Formulations 35-41% Cosmetic ingredient expansion Online B2B Platforms 28-34% Digital procurement Emerging Markets 48-54% Processing capacity expansion

Tallow Market Key Takeaways

At-a-Glance Metrics

Metric Value Market Value (2025) → USD 9.6 billion Market Forecast (2035) ↑ USD 19.7 billion Growth Rate ★ 7.5% CAGR Leading Animal Source → Cattle/Bovine Primary Application → Food & Beverage

The market demonstrates exceptional fundamentals with Cattle/Bovine capturing a commanding 46.3% share through superior availability characteristics, established rendering infrastructure advantages, and proven quality profiles across food processing and industrial applications. Food & Beverage drives primary application demand at 41.8% share, supported by established culinary tradition infrastructure and nutritional requirements that maintain product utilization across diverse cooking segments.

Geographic concentration remains anchored in Asia Pacific and North America with emerging market leadership through livestock processing expansion and rendering infrastructure development, while developed markets show accelerated adoption rates driven by biofuel mandate demographics and oleochemical production preferences.

Imperatives for Stakeholders in Tallow Market

Design for sustainability and traceability, not just animal fat rendering

Offer complete oleochemical solutions: rendered tallow products + quality certification systems + traceability documentation support + application development platforms + sustainability verification services.

Preconfigured supply packages: food-grade specifications, technical-grade formulations, pharmaceutical-grade protocols, and biodiesel feedstock programs for diverse industrial requirements.

Quality readiness for food contact applications

Comprehensive purity documentation, food safety systems, and quality infrastructure (batch traceability, contaminant control, cold chain management protocols).

Affordability-by-design approach

Cost-optimized product portfolios, flexible volume pricing models, customer loyalty programs, and transparent total supply cost documentation.

Technical support-focused market penetration

Established application development workshops + comprehensive certification programs (fatty acid profiling, quality specifications, processing optimization); direct customer engagement for relationship development and product confidence building.

Segmental Analysis

The market segments by animal source into cattle/bovine, sheep/goat, pig, and other animal sources, representing the evolution from traditional bovine rendering toward diverse livestock integration with enhanced supply diversification capabilities, comprehensive quality characteristics, and regional availability optimization.

The application segmentation divides the market into food & beverage (41.8%) with cooking and frying applications, animal/pet feed (26.4%), Pharma/Personal Care & Cosmetics, and Other Industrial including lubricants and biodiesel, reflecting distinct utilization objectives for culinary performance and nutritional content versus specialty chemical processing and renewable energy feedstock requirements.

The distribution channel segmentation shows B2B's commanding 52.1% position and B2C's 21.8% share, followed by online sales, hypermarkets/supermarkets, wholesale stores, and other channels, demonstrating varied commercial transaction levels and supply chain concentrations. The segmentation structure reveals tallow evolution from basic animal fat rendering toward comprehensive oleochemical material platforms with enhanced purity characteristics and multi-dimensional industrial application capabilities, while source diversity spans from conventional cattle processing to specialty sheep and goat materials requiring regional sourcing techniques.

What Makes Cattle/Bovine Command the Largest Share in the Tallow Market?

Cattle/bovine commands the leading position in the tallow market with a 46.3% market share through superior availability characteristics, including established beef processing supply chains, extensive rendering documentation, and standardized quality pathways that enable manufacturers to achieve predictable product outcomes across varied food processing categories and diverse industrial demographics.

The segment benefits from volume advantages through large-scale cattle processing operations, consistent fatty acid composition without requiring specialized fractionation procedures, and established quality validation documentation without extensive material development procedures. Advanced rendering technology enables moisture removal optimization, impurity separation customization, and oxidative stability enhancement, where product consistency and shelf life represent critical application requirements.

Edible-grade bovine tallow formulations hold significant share within the animal source segment, appealing to food processors seeking regulatory compliance capabilities for direct consumption determination. Cattle/bovine tallow products differentiate through proven supply reliability profiles, industry familiarity advantages, and integration with established rendering protocols that enhance production confidence while maintaining compliant quality outcomes for diverse culinary and industrial applications.

Key market characteristics:

Advanced fatty acid properties with balanced saturation profiles and reproducible performance for food processing applications

Superior rendering efficiency, enabling high-yield extraction operations and production scalability for industrial manufacturing

Comprehensive food safety credentials, including HACCP compliance and traceability systems for regulatory approval applications

Why Does Sheep/Goat Represent a Specialized Animal Source Segment?

Sheep/goat sourced tallow maintains specialized market position at 27.6% through alternative livestock characteristics and regional processing capabilities. These products appeal to manufacturers seeking specific fatty acid profiles with unique melting points, offering halal certification advantages and cultural preference alignment through specialized rendering systems. Market adoption is driven by Middle Eastern and Asian applications, emphasizing traditional culinary requirements and religious dietary compliance through certified processing methodologies.

How does Food & Beverage Dominance Shape Application Preferences in Tallow?

Food & beverage demonstrates application leadership in the tallow market with a 41.8% share due to widespread culinary utilization requirements and established focus on cooking performance, flavor stability properties, and high-temperature frying that maximizes food quality while maintaining consistent processing characteristics.

Food processors prioritize tallow products for deep frying applications, baking formulation integration, and compatibility with established food manufacturing workflows that enable coordinated production experiences across multiple product categories. The segment benefits from substantial food safety standardization and flavor profile documentation that emphasizes edible-grade approaches for culinary and confectionery applications across diverse food manufacturing demographics.

Restaurant and foodservice applications capture significant share within the food segment, demonstrating preference for high-heat cooking materials. Fast food industry expansion incorporates tallow as essential frying medium for flavor enhancement, while traditional cuisine preservation increases demand for authentic cooking fat integration with cultural recipe systems for comprehensive culinary heritage outcomes.

What drives Animal/Pet Feed Adoption in Nutritional Supplement Applications?

Animal/pet feed captures substantial application share at 26.4% through comprehensive requirements in energy supplementation systems, palatability enhancement capabilities, and nutritional density optimization.

These products demand sophisticated fatty acid composition protocols capable of achieving feed formulation standards while providing consistent digestibility reliability and processing compatibility, appealing to feed manufacturers and nutrition teams seeking evidence-based performance advantages beyond vegetable oil alternatives.

What Establishes B2B Distribution's Market Leadership in Commercial Channels?

B2B distribution establishes channel leadership in the tallow sector with a 52.1% share due to comprehensive bulk supply requirements and sustained focus on industrial customer service, large-volume transactions, and contract-based procurement that maximizes supply chain efficiency while maintaining appropriate pricing standards.

Manufacturers and processors prioritize B2B channels for bulk tallow purchasing, comprehensive technical support services, and integration with established procurement workflows that enable coordinated supply experiences across multiple production facilities. The sector benefits from substantial industrial relationship infrastructure and contract negotiation expertise that emphasize direct-to-manufacturer delivery for large-scale industrial applications.

Biofuel plant expansion incorporates B2B distribution as standard procurement methodology for feedstock sourcing, while oleochemical manufacturer consolidation increases bulk purchasing that meets volume requirements and ensures supply continuity capabilities.

Distribution dynamics include:

Strong growth in long-term supply agreements requiring price stability and volume guarantee arrangements

Increasing adoption in digital procurement platforms for order efficiency and supply chain visibility positioning

Rising integration with logistics optimization for freight consolidation and delivery scheduling development

How is B2C Distribution Advancing Consumer Market Requirements?

B2C distribution captures substantial channel share at 21.8% through established retail frameworks, consumer packaging capabilities, and integrated brand marketing protocols. The segment demonstrates specialized consumer expertise across diverse retail populations, with advanced small-format packaging applications and brand positioning gaining traction in specialty food programs while retail distribution frameworks drive continued market presence requiring careful balance between premium positioning and price competitiveness assurance.

What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends of the Tallow Market?

Category Factor Impact Why It Matters Driver Rising biofuel production & renewable energy mandates (biodiesel expansion, SAF development) ★★★★★ Environmental regulations enable tallow demand for sustainable fuel feedstock; increasing renewable diesel production drives rendering adoption across energy markets and diverse biofuel segments. Driver Growth in oleochemical manufacturing and industrial chemistry (surfactants, lubricants) ★★★★★ Drives demand for sustainable raw material systems and bio-based chemicals; manufacturers providing renewable alternatives gain competitive advantage in environmentally-focused industrial segments. Driver Livestock processing expansion & meat consumption growth (cattle processing, rendering capacity) ★★★★☆ Processors demand efficient by-product utilization and revenue optimization systems; rendering infrastructure expanding addressable segments beyond traditional tallow demographics and waste management clientele. Restraint Competition from vegetable oils & synthetic alternatives (palm oil, petrochemicals) ★★★★☆ Cost-conscious manufacturers face feedstock choices and substitution pressures, restricting tallow adoption and affecting market penetration in price-sensitive applications and vegetarian-focused segments. Restraint Animal welfare concerns & vegan movement (ethical objections, dietary preferences) ★★★☆☆ Consumers face ethical considerations and dietary restrictions; increases market challenges and affects adoption penetration in plant-based product segments and animal-free consumer populations. Trend Circular economy integration & waste valorization (by-product utilization, zero-waste initiatives) ★★★★★ Growing focus on resource efficiency and waste reduction beyond disposal practices; circular economy positioning becomes core differentiation strategy for sustainable business positioning. Trend Quality standardization & traceability systems (blockchain integration, certification programs) ★★★★☆ Industry evolving beyond commodity trading toward verified supply chains; traceability positioning drives enhanced trust and quality assurance in sophisticated industrial procurement environments.

Analysis of the Tallow Market by Key Countries

The tallow market demonstrates robust regional growth dynamics with emerging leaders including India (9.1% CAGR) and South Africa (8.9% CAGR) driving expansion through livestock processing programs and rendering infrastructure development. Strong performers encompass China (8.4% CAGR), Brazil (7.6% CAGR), and USA (6.9% CAGR), benefiting from established meat processing infrastructure and oleochemical production demographics. Developed markets feature Germany (5.8% CAGR) and UAE (6.4% CAGR), where industrial chemistry normalization and biofuel mandate expertise support consistent growth patterns.

Regional synthesis reveals Asian and African markets leading adoption through comprehensive livestock processing capacity positioning and industrial investment expansion, while Western countries demonstrate measured growth potential supported by biofuel production preferences and oleochemical manufacturing influence. North American markets show solid development driven by rendering industry culture integration and advanced biodiesel production infrastructure.

Region/Country 2025-2035 Growth How to win What to watch out India 9.1% Focus on livestock processing portfolios Infrastructure constraints; quality standardization gaps South Africa 8.9% Lead with regional sourcing positioning Economic volatility; processing capacity limitations China 8.4% Provide biodiesel integration technologies Environmental regulations; import dependencies Brazil 7.6% Offer cattle industry strategies Agricultural cycles; export competition USA 6.9% Maintain biofuel compliance technologies Market maturity; synthetic competition UAE 6.4% Deliver halal certification solutions Import reliance; limited livestock base Germany 5.8% Push oleochemical expertise programs Sustainability pressures; vegetable oil competition

India Drives Fastest Market Growth

India establishes fastest market growth through progressive livestock processing expansion and comprehensive rendering infrastructure development, positioning tallow materials as essential by-product utilization solutions in meat processing centers and emerging oleochemical facilities.

The country's 9.1% growth rate reflects rising cattle processing investment levels supporting animal fat recovery spending and growing biodiesel production segments that encourage the deployment of cost-effective feedstock products in diverse application settings. Growth concentrates in major livestock regions, including Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Punjab, where processing facilities showcase increasing capacity for rendering operation adoption that appeal to meat processors demanding by-product revenue optimization and waste management compliance outcomes.

Indian processors are developing standardized rendering protocols that combine imported purification technologies with domestic livestock processing partnerships, including biodiesel plant expansion and oleochemical manufacturing growth. Distribution channels through industrial chemical distributors and biofuel feedstock suppliers expand market access, while quality training initiatives support adoption across diverse facility types and application specialization levels.

South Africa Emerges as Regional Processing Leader

In Gauteng, Western Cape, and KwaZulu-Natal regions, meat processing facilities and rendering plants are adopting advanced tallow recovery technologies as essential by-product valorization for livestock operations, driven by increasing circular economy alignment with waste reduction standards and elevation of resource efficiency expectations that emphasize the importance of complete animal utilization.

The market holds an 8.9% growth rate, supported by livestock industry development and export infrastructure investment that promote tallow production for domestic and international applications. South African processors are favoring integrated rendering systems that provide comprehensive quality documentation and traceability evidence, particularly appealing in processing clusters where product consistency and certification readiness represent critical operational factors.

Market expansion benefits from substantial meat processing facility investment and rendering capacity establishment that enable widespread adoption of efficient recovery methodologies for diverse cattle and sheep tallow applications. Industry adoption follows patterns established in agricultural efficiency excellence, where by-product revenue advantages and waste reduction optimization drive processor confidence and sustainability achievement.

China Shows Industrial Demand Leadership

China establishes industrial demand leadership through comprehensive oleochemical manufacturing infrastructure and established biodiesel production ecosystem, integrating tallow feedstock across chemical processing facilities, renewable fuel plants, and soap manufacturing organizations.

The country's 8.4% growth rate reflects established industrial chemistry maturity and sophisticated renewable energy levels that support widespread deployment of animal fat feedstock in biofuel and chemical applications. Growth concentrates in established industrial regions, including Shandong, Jiangsu, and Guangdong, where manufacturers showcase advanced oleochemical adoption that appeals to sustainability-focused organizations seeking predictable feedstock quality and comprehensive supply reliability.

Chinese manufacturers leverage established livestock processing relationships and comprehensive supply chain frameworks, including import facilitation systems and quality verification programs that create feedstock confidence and processing assurance. The market benefits from substantial biodiesel capacity expansion and oleochemical development that encourage tallow utilization while supporting continuous application innovation investments and product diversification funding.

Brazil Shows Cattle Industry Integration

Brazil's progressive agricultural market demonstrates established tallow adoption with documented livestock emphasis in cattle processing integration and by-product utilization implementation through specialized meat processors and established rendering operations. The country maintains a 7.6% growth rate, leveraging extensive cattle herd populations and export-focused processing cultures in meat production.

Major cattle regions, including Mato Grosso, São Paulo, and Goiás areas, showcase resource-driven processing priorities where tallow technologies integrate with established beef export operations and regional slaughter capacity to optimize processing economics and maintain by-product revenue under comprehensive agricultural efficiency requirements.

Brazilian processors prioritize export-grade quality strategies and comprehensive cattle industry integration in tallow production, creating demand for certified materials with established traceability, including livestock sourcing documentation, rendering process validation, and quality specification compliance. The market benefits from established beef export industry clusters and large-scale processing capacity that provide supply positioning opportunities and maintain alignment with international quality standards.

USA Shows Biofuel Application Leadership

USA's mature industrial market demonstrates sophisticated tallow integration with documented renewable energy emphasis in biodiesel feedstock application and sustainable aviation fuel development through comprehensive rendering facilities and established biofuel producers.

The country leverages rigorous renewable fuel standards and evidence-based sustainability approaches to maintain a 6.9% growth rate. Premium biofuel centers, including Iowa, California, and Texas, showcase mandate-driven feedstock priorities where tallow materials integrate with established renewable diesel cultures and thorough sustainability practices to optimize carbon intensity reduction and ensure appropriate environmental compliance.

American producers prioritize renewable identification number generation and comprehensive lifecycle analysis in feedstock implementation, creating demand for low-carbon materials with extensive sustainability characteristics, including greenhouse gas reduction documentation, feedstock pathway certification, and comprehensive carbon intensity verification. The market benefits from established renewable diesel segments and biofuel mandate maturity that provide premium positioning opportunities and compliance with strict EPA renewable fuel requirements.

UAE Demonstrates Halal Certification Preferences

UAE's growing consumer market demonstrates established tallow integration with documented religious focus in halal certification compliance and food application protocols through comprehensive import networks and specialized distribution organizations. The country maintains a 6.4% growth rate, leveraging Islamic dietary requirement alignment with food safety standards and established import infrastructure in food processing.

Key commercial centers, including Dubai and Abu Dhabi, showcase certification-driven sourcing approaches where tallow materials integrate with established halal verification cultures and comprehensive traceability systems to optimize religious compliance and maintain food safety standards under evolving consumer requirements.

UAE importers prioritize comprehensive halal documentation and Islamic authority certification in supply program development, creating demand for verified products with extensive religious compliance, including halal slaughter certification, processing facility approval, and cleanliness protocol documentation. The market benefits from established food import sectors and halal certification infrastructure that provide positioning opportunities and maintain alignment with stringent UAE food safety regulations.

Germany Shows Oleochemical Integration

Germany's advanced chemical market demonstrates progressive tallow adoption with documented industrial standards in oleochemical formulation and specialty application execution through established chemical manufacturers and specialized processing facilities. The country maintains a 5.8% growth rate, leveraging established chemical industry heritage and comprehensive quality oversight frameworks in surfactant manufacturing.

Major chemical centers, including North Rhine-Westphalia and Bavaria regions, showcase traditional quality emphasis where tallow materials integrate with established European chemical standards and meticulous processing practices to optimize product quality assurance and maintain sustainability compliance under comprehensive environmental supervision.

German manufacturers prioritize bio-based content requirements and comprehensive sustainability system integration in formulation development, creating demand for renewable materials with extensive documentation characteristics, including lifecycle assessment data, biodegradability testing, and comprehensive environmental product declarations. The market benefits from established oleochemical manufacturing reputation and quality-focused production culture that provide premium positioning opportunities and comply with strict German chemical regulations.

Europe Market Split by Country

The European tallow market is projected to grow from USD 2.1 billion in 2025 to USD 3.7 billion by 2035, representing 22.0% of the global market in 2025 and expanding to 18.8% by 2035. Germany is expected to maintain its leadership position with USD 0.5 billion in 2025, accounting for 26.8% of the European market, supported by its advanced oleochemical manufacturing infrastructure and established rendering networks.

France follows with USD 0.4 billion, representing 18.9% of the European market in 2025, driven by comprehensive livestock processing integration and chemical industry concentration. UK holds USD 0.4 billion with 17.3% market share through established biodiesel production acceptance and rendering facility density.

Italy commands USD 0.3 billion representing 14.2% share, while Spain accounts for USD 0.2 billion or 11.6% in 2025. The rest of Europe region maintains USD 0.2 billion, representing 11.2% of the European market, attributed to increasing tallow adoption in Nordic countries and emerging Eastern European biofuel sectors implementing renewable feedstock programs.

Competitive Landscape of the Tallow Market

The tallow market exhibits a moderately fragmented competitive structure with approximately 70-100 active players operating across global rendering networks and regional livestock processing distribution portfolios. Darling Ingredients maintains market leadership at a 12.7% share, reflecting strong rendering capacity positioning across diverse livestock sources with sophisticated global supply strategies.

This competitive landscape demonstrates the maturation of tallow technology, where established players leverage rendering scale advantages, extensive livestock processor relationships, and quality system documentation to maintain dominant positions, while emerging regional renderers and specialty processors create niche opportunities through localized sourcing offerings and competitive quality strategies.

Market leadership is maintained through several critical competitive advantages extending beyond rendering capabilities and product portfolios. Global collection networks enable leading players to navigate diverse livestock processing requirements and access varied customer segments including biofuel producers, oleochemical manufacturers, and food processors.

Quality assurance infrastructure and traceability program availability represent crucial differentiators in tallow categories, where decades of rendering expertise, contaminant control protocols, and certification frameworks create purchasing preference among quality-focused industrial customers.

Processing efficiency in large-scale rendering facilities, supply chain logistics management, and raw material sourcing capabilities separate major suppliers from smaller competitors, while comprehensive quality documentation addressing fatty acid profiles, purity specifications, and sustainability data strengthen market position and customer confidence.

The market demonstrates emerging differentiation opportunities in specialty-grade categories and sustainable sourcing technologies, where traditional commodity tallow materials face competition from innovation-focused entrants offering traceability advantages. However, significant competitive advantages persist in established edible and technical-grade categories through comprehensive cost-effectiveness profiles and supply reliability depth. Premium positioning strategies with quality certification capabilities and sustainable sourcing verification command margin premiums through superior purity and environmental credentials.

Specialized product portfolios combining multiple grade offerings with application-specific purification create comprehensive positioning that justifies higher price points beyond commodity tallow competition. Integrated rendering solution offerings emphasizing complementary by-product utilization compatibility, unified technical support, and cross-application material expertise generate brand loyalty and product line preferences beyond transactional commodity purchases.

title: LanzaJet makes first commercial ethanol jet fuel - EcoHubMap
description:
LanzaJet makes first commercial ethanol jet fuel LanzaJet, a leading U.S. sustainable fuel innovator, has announced a major breakthrough: the successful production of jet fuel made from ethanol at its Freedom Pines Fuels plant in Soperton, Georgia.
This achievement marks the world’s first commercial-scale output of ethanol-derived jet fuel, delivering a renewable, non-petroleum aviation fuel that works seamlessly with today’s aircraft and fueling infrastructure.
LanzaJet highlights this advancement as a major step forward for farmers, biofuels producers, aviation stakeholders, and climate-focused innovators.
“This achievement represents the culmination of 15 years of research, collaboration, investment, and scale-up—and it proves ethanol can be transformed into jet fuel at true commercial scale,” the company stated.
Why ethanol matters: a scalable solution for SAF production Aviation faces urgent pressure to decarbonize, and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) remains the only scalable near-term solution for reducing emissions from long-haul flights.
text:
LanzaJet makes first commercial ethanol jet fuel

LanzaJet, a leading U.S. sustainable fuel innovator, has announced a major breakthrough: the successful production of jet fuel made from ethanol at its Freedom Pines Fuels plant in Soperton, Georgia. This achievement marks the world’s first commercial-scale output of ethanol-derived jet fuel, delivering a renewable, non-petroleum aviation fuel that works seamlessly with today’s aircraft and fueling infrastructure. Backed by more than 15 years of research and development, the milestone validates LanzaJet’s proprietary Alcohol-to-Jet (ATJ) technology, a platform capable of converting a wide range of sustainable feedstocks—including agricultural waste, purpose-grown energy crops, municipal solid waste, and captured carbon—into drop-in aviation fuel. LanzaJet highlights this advancement as a major step forward for farmers, biofuels producers, aviation stakeholders, and climate-focused innovators. “This achievement represents the culmination of 15 years of research, collaboration, investment, and scale-up—and it proves ethanol can be transformed into jet fuel at true commercial scale,” the company stated.

Why ethanol matters: a scalable solution for SAF production

Aviation faces urgent pressure to decarbonize, and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) remains the only scalable near-term solution for reducing emissions from long-haul flights. However, the current dominant SAF pathway—HEFA (Hydroprocessed Esters and Fatty Acids)—depends heavily on limited feedstocks such as used cooking oil and waste fats. With global demand rising, these resources are quickly being constrained. LanzaJet’s ATJ pathway offers a critical alternative by leveraging widely available ethanol. Through a continuous catalytic conversion process, ethanol is transformed into Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (SPK) via: • Dehydration – converting ethanol into ethylene • Oligomerization – building longer hydrocarbon chains • Hydrogenation/Hydrotreating – refining chains into kerosene-range molecules The result is a fully certified SAF compatible with existing turbines, pipelines, and airport systems. CEO Jimmy Samartzis noted, “This milestone is a major win for global aviation and a sign of what’s possible for the industry’s future.” According to LanzaJet, ATJ is the most commercially ready, scalable SAF solution developed in the past decade, supporting energy security, domestic fuel production, and growth in agricultural economies.

Higher-quality fuel with lower emissions

The Freedom Pines Fuels facility stands as a first-of-its-kind (FOAK) integrated biorefinery, representing more than $300 million in investment. The plant incorporates cutting-edge technologies such as: • Technip Energies’ Hummingbird system (Ethanol-to-Ethylene) • A combined DOE/LanzaTech Oligomerization process By sourcing from a diverse blend of sustainable feedstocks, the plant delivers SAF with substantially lower lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions compared to fossil-based jet fuel. When blended with Jet A-1, the resulting fuel meets all international aviation standards, offering a drop-in solution for airlines worldwide. LanzaJet reports that its SAF delivers higher energy density than conventional Jet-A, providing a superior-quality fuel while reducing environmental impact. Beyond its climate benefits, the Freedom Pines facility is generating economic value in rural Georgia—creating hundreds of construction jobs and supporting more than 65 permanent direct and indirect jobs in Treutlen County.

Global deployment and the road to net zero aviation

LanzaJet is scaling its ATJ technology worldwide, with projects already underway across: • United States • Australia • Japan • India • United Kingdom • Colombia • European Union • Middle East • Kazakhstan As the aviation sector targets Net Zero by 2050, LanzaJet’s success demonstrates that the technologies needed to accelerate deep decarbonization are not theoretical—they exist today.

title: Brasil faz acordo de exportações com Filipinas, Guatemala e Nicarágua - ISTOÉ DINHEIRO
authors: Agência Brasil, Agência Brasil https:, istoedinheiro.com.br, agencia-brasil
description:
O governo brasileiro concluiu negociações sanitárias e fitossanitárias com Filipinas, Guatemala e Nicarágua para aumentar exportações de produtos agropecuários para esses países.
Entre janeiro e outubro de 2025, o país do sudeste asiático importou quase US$ 1,5 bilhão em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.
Entre janeiro e outubro de 2025, a Nicarágua importou cerca de US$ 55 milhões em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.
Já na Guatemala, o governo brasileiro obteve autorização fitossanitária para exportar arroz beneficiado.
Em 2025, até outubro, o país importou mais de US$ 192 milhões em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.
text:
O governo brasileiro concluiu negociações sanitárias e fitossanitárias com Filipinas, Guatemala e Nicarágua para aumentar exportações de produtos agropecuários para esses países.

Nas Filipinas, as autoridades sanitárias aprovaram a exportação de gordura bovina, insumo utilizado na indústria de alimentos e na produção de energia de baixo carbono, especialmente o diesel verde e o sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

Notícias relacionadas:

Exportações brasileiras batem recorde em outubro, apesar de tarifaço.

Brasil busca fortalecer laços com a África no setor agrícola.

Entre janeiro e outubro de 2025, o país do sudeste asiático importou quase US$ 1,5 bilhão em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.

Na Nicarágua, as autoridades fitossanitárias autorizaram o Brasil a exportar sementes de milheto, crotalária e nabo, insumos para a agricultura tropical, que contribuem para o aumento da produtividade e a redução da dependência de fertilizantes minerais. Entre janeiro e outubro de 2025, a Nicarágua importou cerca de US$ 55 milhões em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.

Já na Guatemala, o governo brasileiro obteve autorização fitossanitária para exportar arroz beneficiado. Em 2025, até outubro, o país importou mais de US$ 192 milhões em produtos agropecuários do Brasil.

title: BREAKING: Airbus Announces Major Recall on Over 6000 A320-family Jets Following Incident
description:
Airbus has announced an urgent recall affecting approximately 6,000 A320-family aircraft worldwide following a serious flight-control malfunction linked to corrupted data, the company confirmed earlier this afternoon (Friday 28 November 2025).
The recall covers more than half of all A320-family jets in service and comes after an incident last month in which a JetBlue flight experienced an unexpected loss of altitude and diverted for an emergency landing.
Flight-Control Failure Triggers Global Response The recall stems from an October 30 incident involving a JetBlue flight en route from Cancun to Newark.
The aircraft abruptly descended due to corrupted flight-control data believed to have been caused by intense solar radiation exposure.
Airbus said the issue, while rare, could potentially affect any A320-family jet operating under certain environmental conditions.
text:
Airbus has announced an urgent recall affecting approximately 6,000 A320-family aircraft worldwide following a serious flight-control malfunction linked to corrupted data, the company confirmed earlier this afternoon (Friday 28 November 2025). The recall covers more than half of all A320-family jets in service and comes after an incident last month in which a JetBlue flight experienced an unexpected loss of altitude and diverted for an emergency landing.

The European Union Aviation Safety Agency is preparing an Emergency Airworthiness Directive that will mandate inspections and software updates before affected aircraft can return to service.

Flight-Control Failure Triggers Global Response

The recall stems from an October 30 incident involving a JetBlue flight en route from Cancun to Newark. The aircraft abruptly descended due to corrupted flight-control data believed to have been caused by intense solar radiation exposure. Several passengers were hospitalized after the emergency landing in Tampa.

Airbus said the issue, while rare, could potentially affect any A320-family jet operating under certain environmental conditions. The manufacturer emphasized that correcting the vulnerability requires immediate action across the global fleet.

In a statement, the manufacturer said:

“Analysis of a recent event involving an A320 Family aircraft has revealed that intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls. Airbus has consequently identified a significant number of A320 Family aircraft currently in-service which may be impacted.”

Software Rollbacks and Hardware Fixes Expected

Airbus has instructed operators to install updated software without delay. Roughly two-thirds of affected aircraft will need only a rapid software rollback, allowing them to return to service quickly. However, hundreds of jets will require hardware modifications, a process that could ground them for weeks.

The company warned that the recall will likely cause schedule disruptions for airlines and passengers but reiterated that safety remains its top priority.

Airlines operating the A319, A320 and A321 models are already coordinating with regulators to determine when grounded aircraft can safely re-enter service.

title: Airlines warn EU261 plan is heading off-track and becoming a 'reverse Robin Hood'
description:
European governments attempted to address these in June, when the European Council backed amendments designed to safeguard connectivity and strengthen the competitiveness of European aviation.
This, IATA said, would reduce incentives for airlines to cancel delayed flights, while aligning with passengers’ clear preference to arrive late rather than not at all.
This, it argued, includes phasing out passenger taxes that undermine connectivity; Sweden removed its levy in July, and IATA urged others to follow.
At present, airlines face a USD 2.9 billion premium for purchasing SAF compared with conventional jet fuel, on top of ETS costs.
IATA described the Commission’s recent STIP proposal as a positive signal, although it said concrete action remains to be seen.
text:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has warned that the European Parliament’s proposed overhaul of EU261 risks moving the bloc’s passenger-rights rules in the wrong direction, arguing that the changes would raise costs for travellers and airlines while failing to address the issues passengers actually face.

According to IATA, the regulation’s shortcomings have been evident for years. European governments attempted to address these in June, when the European Council backed amendments designed to safeguard connectivity and strengthen the competitiveness of European aviation.

Although not perfect, that position aimed for a more balanced framework, notably by increasing the delay thresholds for compensation from three hours to four hours for short-haul flights, and to six hours for long-haul services.

This, IATA said, would reduce incentives for airlines to cancel delayed flights, while aligning with passengers’ clear preference to arrive late rather than not at all.

The Parliament, however, is pushing to scrap these threshold changes and introduce additional obligations, including a right to bring a cabin bag for free.

IATA noted that there is no evidence passengers are asking for such measures, and even less that they are willing to pay higher fares for them.

In its May passenger survey, 72 per cent said they preferred the lowest fare with the option to pay for extra services when needed.

At the same time, 97 per cent reported being satisfied with their most recent flight.

Eurocontrol data also shows that fewer than 1 per cent of flights face delays longer than three hours, meaning the remaining 99 per cent of passengers are funding a compensation scheme that only a small minority ever uses.

IATA argues this makes value for money even more important.

Willie Walsh, IATA’s Director General, said the Parliament’s approach effectively “works as a reverse Robin Hood”, adding that “there is no such thing as a ‘free’ bag or ‘free’ compensation thresholds”.

He stressed that “MEPs are imposing things people haven’t asked for, and don’t want to pay for unless they choose to”, noting that passengers would rather pay lower fares in exchange for a less “gold-plated” scheme.

He added that the Council’s position should be upheld to support competitiveness and reflect the calls in last year’s Draghi report for fewer and smarter regulations.

IATA also linked the debate to broader concerns over Europe’s slowing air-connectivity growth. Its research shows that between 2014 and 2024, connectivity grew by only 2.2 per cent a year in France, 2.9 per cent in the Netherlands, and just 0.4 per cent in Germany, trends it says emphasise the need for action to help the industry remain competitive.

This, it argued, includes phasing out passenger taxes that undermine connectivity; Sweden removed its levy in July, and IATA urged others to follow.

It also called for changes to the ReFuelEU “Green Deal” Regulation and the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, saying fuel producers should be incentivised to supply affordable sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), while airlines need to benefit from using it.

At present, airlines face a USD 2.9 billion premium for purchasing SAF compared with conventional jet fuel, on top of ETS costs. IATA described the Commission’s recent STIP proposal as a positive signal, although it said concrete action remains to be seen.

Finally, IATA warned that the combination of rising regulatory, environmental and tax-related costs is already undermining the viability of new routes and additional frequencies, ultimately reducing choice for consumers.

title: UAE travel alert: Airlines respond to global Airbus A320 recall disruption
description:
Airbus issued the directive on Friday, calling for an immediate software update across the A320 fleet.
Airline responses UAE-based confirmed it has initiated mandatory software and technical upgrades across its affected A320 aircraft.
Global response Carriers across Europe, Asia, and North America have begun fleet assessments to determine the number of affected aircraft.
Air India confirmed that over 40 per cent of its affected fleet has already been updated, with no flight cancellations reported so far.
Similarly, Flynas in Saudi Arabia has begun carrying out software and technical recalibrations across part of its A320 fleet.
text:
DUBAI – in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and worldwide are navigating widespread operational checks prompted by an directive impacting the A320 family, one of the world’s most widely used aircraft types.

The precautionary move follows concerns about a potential flight-control issue linked to intense solar radiation. Airlines, regulators, and passengers across continents are monitoring the developments, with up to 6,000 jets worldwide requiring software or hardware modifications.

While some disruptions are expected, UAE carriers have responded quickly, prioritising safety and operational continuity.

Airbus issued the directive on Friday, calling for an immediate software update across the A320 fleet. The update affects aircraft equipped with a specific flight-control component known as the Elevator Aileron Computer (ELAC). The precautionary order is being treated with urgency by operators across the Middle East, Europe, Asia, and the United States. Most jets will receive a software update taking approximately three hours, while around 900 older aircraft will require hardware replacement, temporarily grounding affected planes.

Airline responses

UAE-based confirmed it has initiated mandatory software and technical upgrades across its affected A320 aircraft. The Sharjah-based budget carrier operates 67 A320 family aircraft through its operations in Sharjah and Abu Dhabi, making it one of the UAE’s largest operators of the model.

“We confirm that we have received the directive issued by Airbus concerning the A320 aircraft type operated by airlines worldwide, which requires a number of aircraft to undergo specific software and technical updates,” a spokesperson said. The airline assured travellers that measures were being implemented across the impacted fleet and that any schedule adjustments would be communicated directly to affected passengers. “We are working to ensure minimal impact on our customers. In the event of any schedule adjustments, affected passengers will be notified directly.”

Air Arabia expressed regret for any inconvenience, emphasising its commitment to the highest levels of safety.

Meanwhile, Airways announced that its A320 operations have already returned to a normal schedule after completing the required update swiftly. The Abu Dhabi-based airline credited its operational teams for minimising disruption, especially during one of the busiest travel periods at Zayed International Airport ahead of the long weekend.

“Thanks to the exceptional efforts of our operational and technical teams, the update was completed quickly and with minimal disruption,” Etihad said. The carrier highlighted the importance of passenger understanding and reaffirmed that safety remains the airline’s top priority.

According to aviation data and analytics firm Cirium, UAE airlines collectively operate 106 Airbus A320-family aircraft, a significant portion of the regional fleet. The A320 is a preferred model globally, known for its fuel efficiency, versatility, and range of up to 4,700 nautical miles. Globally, around half of Airbus’s total commercial fleet—some 6,000 aircraft—fall under the recall directive.

The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) explained that intense solar radiation may, in rare cases, affect data used by the ELAC system, potentially leading to uncommanded movement of the aircraft’s control surfaces. While no major accidents have been directly attributed to the issue, the advisory was issued under safety precaution guidelines.

Global response

Carriers across Europe, Asia, and North America have begun fleet assessments to determine the number of affected aircraft. In , operators including IndiGo, Air India, and Air India Express are implementing software and hardware realignments across around 200–250 aircraft, according to aviation authorities. Air India confirmed that over 40 per cent of its affected fleet has already been updated, with no flight cancellations reported so far. However, travellers have been advised to expect possible delays.

Similarly, Flynas in Saudi Arabia has begun carrying out software and technical recalibrations across part of its A320 fleet. The airline warned of longer turnaround times on a limited number of flights and said that any affected passengers would be contacted via SMS or email.

In Japan, All Nippon Airways (ANA) reported the cancellation of 65 domestic flights. The carrier confirmed that 34 of its A320-family aircraft required the update, affecting thousands of passengers travelling in and out of Haneda Airport in Tokyo. Japan Airlines, however, confirmed its fleet was unaffected.

Impact on airports

In the United Kingdom, Gatwick Airport reported that approximately 80 aircraft were affected. While Heathrow confirmed no major operational impact, airlines are coordinating parking and overnight update schedules to minimise disruption.

In the United States, American Airlines reported that 340 aircraft would undergo inspection and update, with many expected to be completed by Saturday. Delta said fewer than 50 of its A321neo aircraft were affected and anticipates limited disruption. United Airlines and Hawaiian Airlines said their fleets were unaffected.

Technical fixes

The required repair process primarily involves reverting aircraft systems to earlier software versions. The ELAC units receive a software patch to safeguard against corrupted flight-control data. For the older aircraft requiring hardware replacement, the process is more complex and may involve transporting aircraft to maintenance facilities. Ferry flights, where aircraft are flown without passengers to maintenance hubs, are permitted under regulated safety guidelines.

Regulatory oversight

The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) in India has issued an airworthiness directive banning the operation of certain A320-family aircraft without the mandated modification. “No person shall operate any aircraft that falls under the applicability of this mandatory modification except those complying with the requirements,” the order said.

The directive listed multiple Airbus models, including A319, A320 ceos and neos, and A321 variants, underscoring the scale of the global impact.

Passenger advisory

As airlines work to implement the updates, passengers are advised to monitor notifications, maintain updated contact details, and check flight statuses before travelling to the airport. Carriers have reiterated that no major safety incidents have been linked to the issue and that the directive is precautionary.

The software anomaly came into focus after a JetBlue A320 experienced a sudden drop in altitude during a flight from Cancun, Mexico, to Newark, New Jersey, in late October. The aircraft made an emergency landing in Tampa, Florida, with minor injuries reported for 15 passengers. The investigation pointed to potential data corruption within the ELAC system, prompting Airbus and EASA to issue a global directive.

Airbus describes the A320 family as the “aircraft of choice for airlines around the world.” With seating for 120 to 244 passengers, modern A320 aircraft already operate partially using sustainable aviation fuel, with Airbus targeting 100 per cent use by 2030. Its advanced turbofan engines offer up to 20 per cent reductions in fuel burn compared with earlier models.

As airlines continue to implement updates, global regulators reiterate that safety remains the absolute priority of the aviation industry, with operational continuity managed closely alongside compliance efforts.

title: Ethiopia Ready To Gamble On Sustainable Aviation Fuel
description:
Ethiopia has formally begun positioning itself as a producer of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) following the conclusion of a national feasibility study which confirmed that the country has both the land and renewable energy capacity for supplying the emerging global aviation fuel market.
Municipal waste presented a dual opportunity allowing the country to simultaneously address urban waste problems while generating clean aviation fuel, according to the technical team.
Electricity-based fuel production was identified as one of Ethiopia’s strongest long-term options due to its high renewable energy potential, offering a future route for hydrogen-based synthetic fuel manufacturing.
Consultants acknowledged current market prices for sustainable aviation fuel are roughly double conventional jet fuel rates, though they expect long-term costs to fall once production maturity is achieved.
The government confirmed the formation of a national technical committee on sustainable aviation fuel and announced plans to establish a project office staffed by aviation and energy specialists in the coming weeks.
text:
Ethiopia has formally begun positioning itself as a producer of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) following the conclusion of a national feasibility study which confirmed that the country has both the land and renewable energy capacity for supplying the emerging global aviation fuel market.

During a multi-stakeholder validation workshop held in Addis Ababa’s Skylight Hotel on Thursday November 27, experts presenting the feasibility study told officials and industry representatives that Ethiopia could produce low-carbon aviation fuel using local agricultural crops, municipal waste, sugar byproducts and renewable energy sources.

The findings were presented to senior representatives from the ministries of Transport and Logistics, Agriculture, the Civil Aviation Authority, universities and private investors during a final validation workshop attended by international consultants and donors, including the European Union, which funded the study through the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO)

The feasibility study launched in December 2024 with a national workshop and followed by field consultations and a March 2025 stakeholder conference, where Ethiopian officials engaged with technical experts to review data and evaluate business readiness for domestic SAF production.

The research built on three previous studies including a 2019 WWF-South Africa assessment and two Ethiopian roadmap and feasibility studies conducted in 2021 and 2022, which first identified Ethiopian mustard as a viable aviation fuel crop.

Lead consultant John McKechnie stated that Ethiopia was selected for deeper analysis because of its agricultural base, expanding industrial capacity and unexploited renewable energy resources, which together position the country strategically in Africa’s energy transition.

Researchers confirmed that more than 30 million hectares of Ethiopian land are suitable for cultivating Ethiopian mustard without interfering with food production, making it one of the most promising non-food crops identified for sustainable aviation fuel feedstock.

Field trials already show the crop can be produced at scale, though further research is required to determine how national production can be expanded to serve commercial aviation demand.

Officials acknowledged challenges related to logistics and supply chains, noting that Ethiopia’s farmers are geographically dispersed and current transport infrastructure makes bulk feedstock collection difficult.

The study examined multiple production routes including alcohol-to-jet fuel derived from sugar molasses, waste-to-fuel systems using municipal landfill material, and electricity-based fuels derived from renewable sources.

Ethiopia’s sugar sector already has an annual ethanol production capacity of approximately 32.5 million liters, though current output remains constrained due to competition from food and beverage manufacturers willing to pay higher prices.

Municipal waste presented a dual opportunity allowing the country to simultaneously address urban waste problems while generating clean aviation fuel, according to the technical team.

Electricity-based fuel production was identified as one of Ethiopia’s strongest long-term options due to its high renewable energy potential, offering a future route for hydrogen-based synthetic fuel manufacturing.

Power-to-liquid technology is projected to be certified between mid-2026 and late-2026, placing Ethiopia within range of early commercial adoption provided investment mobilization begins promptly.

Consultants acknowledged current market prices for sustainable aviation fuel are roughly double conventional jet fuel rates, though they expect long-term costs to fall once production maturity is achieved.

An international benchmark drawn from India revealed that mandatory aviation fuel blending will begin at one percent in 2027 and rise to five percent by 2030.

Experts warned airlines that regulatory pressure will intensify across international airspace, with compliance becoming unavoidable by 2030 if Ethiopian carriers are to maintain global competitiveness.

The government confirmed the formation of a national technical committee on sustainable aviation fuel and announced plans to establish a project office staffed by aviation and energy specialists in the coming weeks.

Officials stated development partners would be invited to finance the project office and assist in converting research findings into industrial investment programs. Transport Ministry officials reiterated that aviation alone accounts for a large share of global emissions and that Ethiopia has committed to carbon-reduction targets under international climate agreements.

title: TRA proposes new countervailing duties on USA HVO biodiesel - BioEnergy Times
description:
The Trade Remedies Authority (TRA) has released its Statement of Essential Facts on imports of hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) biodiesel from the United States, according to the press release.
The investigation, which began on 17 March 2025, focuses on HVO biodiesel — also known as renewable or green diesel.
After reviewing evidence that subsidised imports are harming UK biodiesel manufacturers, the TRA has outlined its planned final recommendation for a fixed duty, proposing countervailing duties ranging from £257.80 to £303.56 per tonne.
The TRA has invited interested parties to submit their comments on these initial conclusions through the Trade Remedies Service by 19 December 2025.
In a separate decision, the TRA has closed its parallel investigation into dumped HVO biodiesel imports from the US, stating that there was not enough substantial evidence to prove dumping.
text:
The Trade Remedies Authority (TRA) has released its Statement of Essential Facts on imports of hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) biodiesel from the United States, according to the press release.

The investigation, which began on 17 March 2025, focuses on HVO biodiesel — also known as renewable or green diesel.

After reviewing evidence that subsidised imports are harming UK biodiesel manufacturers, the TRA has outlined its planned final recommendation for a fixed duty, proposing countervailing duties ranging from £257.80 to £303.56 per tonne.

The TRA has invited interested parties to submit their comments on these initial conclusions through the Trade Remedies Service by 19 December 2025.

In a separate decision, the TRA has closed its parallel investigation into dumped HVO biodiesel imports from the US, stating that there was not enough substantial evidence to prove dumping.
