title: Expander Announces Progress In Biomass Based E-Fuels Project In Mackenzie, British Columbia
description:
The Mackenzie Biofuel Project will become the first of kind low carbon clean fuel production in British Columbia and Canada using forestry wood waste biomass (cellulose).
Expander is also very pleased to announce that community and Indigenous leaders / organizations have provided their support for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project.
The McLeod Lake Indian Band (“MLIB”) and the District of Mackenzie (“Mackenzie”) have provided letters of support for further development of the project.
The Mackenzie Biofuel Project is one of the three projects identified in the feasibility study completed earlier this year.
Contact Information Expander Energy Inc. Gord N. Crawford, P.Eng.
text:
Calgary, Alberta, Nov 27, 2025 – TheNewswire - Expander Energy Inc. (“Expander”) is pleased to announce that a letter of intent has been signed with East Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd. (“East Fraser”) to secure the required biomass feedstock and land for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project, a proposed Biomass Electrolysis to Liquids (BETL®) Bio-Synfuel facility in Mackenzie, British Columbia (BC).

BETL is an innovative, patented and patent pending process for making low carbon bio-synthetic fuels developed by Canadian Nuclear Laboratories (CNL) and Expander which leverages Expander’s technology for biomass gasification, bio-synthetic fuel production, and electrolysis technology. The resulting fuel will be comprised entirely of carbon sourced from biogenic (atmospheric) sources and is expected to have very low life cycle carbon intensity.

The proposed facility will utilize the BETL® technology to convert 84,000 dry tonnes per year of forestry wood waste into 30 million liters per year of renewable diesel, renewable naphtha and bio-wax with life cycle carbon intensity of the fuel to levels 80% lower than fossil equivalents (as low as 14 gCO2e/MJ using the BC Low Carbon Fuels Branch (BCLCFS) GHGenius LCA model). The biofuel production is intended to displace fossil derived fuels (e.g., diesel, aviation fuel) and could result in a net avoidance of up to 90,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide annually. The 100km area surrounding Mackenzie has significant fiber resources. Expander will assess the potential to scale the Mackenzie Biofuel Project to process a total of 336,000 tonnes of dry biomass per year to produce 120 million litres per year Bio-Synfuel production and net avoidance of 360,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per year.

Growing global demand for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) makes the addition of Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (FT- SPK) production to the facility commercially appealing. Expander is currently working with key strategic commercial partners from the aviation industry to assess initial market interest in 18 million liters/year of SAF, with potential opportunity to expand SAF to 72 million liters/year production. The Mackenzie Biofuel Project will become the first of kind low carbon clean fuel production in British Columbia and Canada using forestry wood waste biomass (cellulose). This facility could meet much of the short-term SAF target for British Columbia.

Expander is also very pleased to announce that community and Indigenous leaders / organizations have provided their support for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project. The McLeod Lake Indian Band (“MLIB”) and the District of Mackenzie (“Mackenzie”) have provided letters of support for further development of the project.

The Mackenzie Biofuel Project is one of the three projects identified in the feasibility study completed earlier this year. Expander aims to continue the development of the project with the goal to secure funding early in 2026, with production by 2029. Natural Resources Canada through the Clean Fuels Fund program supported the completion of a feasibility study that helped to identify several prospect locations across Canada, one of which was this Mackenzie site. The Clean Fuels Fund has also supported the Front-End Engineering and Design (FEED) study that is expected to be complete in early 2026 and will result in a comprehensive facility design, cost, schedule and business plan for the Mackenzie Biofuel Project.

The completed facility will be a global showcase for next generation biomass based E-fuel production.

“We are thrilled to announce significant progress on the Mackenzie Biofuels Project. Over the past 18 months, our development team has worked tirelessly, and we are on track to complete the fully funded $8 million FEED study by Q1 2026. With land and feedstock secured, and strong support from key community and Indigenous leaders, we are now able to accelerate the project.” said Steve Kresnyak, Executive Vice President and Chief Technology Officer, Expander Energy Inc. “In addition, Expander Energy Inc. is actively engaging with strategic partners to secure project funding. We look forward to sharing more details as these partnerships are finalized, marking another step toward delivering price competitive Biomass based E-fuels for Industry and Aviation”

“It is truly exciting to see the BETL® Bio-Synfuel process progress to this stage. Achieving this new supply agreement brings the technology another step closer towards the production of economical, ready-to-deploy, renewable fuels,” commented Dr. Stephen Bushby, CNL’s Vice-President of Science and Technology. “This project leverages Canada’s expertise and capabilities in hydrogen and hydrogen isotopes – originally built in support of the nuclear sector, to advance bold, innovative ideas towards deployment. This demonstrates the true spirit of collaboration, working together to overcome challenges and find solutions.”

“East Fraser Fiber sees the production of Biomass based E-fuels as an important compliment to existing commercial operations in the Mackenzie BC area, with the potential for additional facilities at other Parallel Lumber Group facilities in Canada and the USA.” Said Ante Cirko – Vice President - East Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd.

“The MacLeod Lake Indian Band is committed to environmentally responsible development of natural resources within our traditional lands that are consistent with the values of the Tse’khene people and provide significant economic opportunities in the region for decades to come.” Said Chief Harley Chingee – MacLeod Lake Indian Band

“The District of Mackenzie is thrilled to welcome a Biomass Electrolysis to Liquids Plant to our community. The past few years have been extremely challenging as residents watched our tax base shrink and community members suffer job losses. The Mackenzie Bio-Synfuels facility is a huge step forward in promoting economic growth for our community and the region. Their advanced proven technology will also provide additional support to our forest industry with their utilization of forest harvesting residuals. We are excited our community will be a participant in this sustainable solution that will reduce use of fossil fuels, while removing “wildfire fuels” from the forests surrounding Mackenzie.” said Mayor Joan Atkinson – District of Mackenzie

About Expander Energy Inc.

Expander Energy Inc. is a Calgary, Alberta-based energy technology company that has developed a patented suite of transportation fuel production technologies to convert biomass, captured carbon and low Carbon Intensity electricity into “fossil free” low life cycle carbon intensity synthetic diesel fuel (Bio-SynDiesel®) and synthetic kerosene jet fuel (Bio-SynJet®). Expander’s Bio-Energy Carbon Capture and Sequestration (BECCS) solution utilizes cellulosic biomass to produce next generation low CI synthetic fuels while efficiently capturing bio-carbon for geologic sequestration. Bio-SynDiesel®, Bio-SynJet®, BGTL®, EBTL®, BETL®, and CETL® are trademarks of Expander Energy Inc.

About Canadian Nuclear Labs

As Canada’s premier nuclear science and technology laboratory and working under the direction of Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL), CNL is a world leader in the development of innovative nuclear science and technology products and services. Guided by an ambitious corporate strategy known as Vision 2030, CNL fulfills three strategic priorities of national importance – restoring and protecting the environment, advancing clean energy technologies, and contributing to the health of Canadians. To learn more about CNL, please visit www.cnl.ca

About East Fraser Fiber Inc.

East Fraser Fiber Co. Ltd. is a Canadian wood-product manufacturer that produces finger-joint studs, trim blocks, and wood chips, serving the North American construction market. Founded in 1990 by the Glazier brothers, the company is part of the Parallel Lumber Group. For more information, please see www.plbrg.com

About the McLeod Lake Indian Band

The McLeod Lake Indian Band (MLIB) is part of the Tse’khene group of Aboriginal peoples, including bands at Fort Ware (Kwadacha) and Ingenika (Tseh Kay Dene). The main community of McLeod Lake Band is located on McLeod Lake Indian Band Indian Reserves #1 and #5 near the unincorporated village of McLeod Lake, approximately 150 kilometres north of Prince George on Highway 97. For more information, please see www.mlib.ca

About the District of Mackenzie.

The District of Mackenzie is a friendly, planned community of approximately 3,700 residents in north-central British Columbia, known for its natural resource-based industries (primarily forestry, mining, and bio-fuel) and abundant outdoor recreation opportunities. For more information visit www.districtofmackenzie.ca

title: Pau : l'aéroport reçoit les pionniers de l'aviation décarbonée - Sud Ouest
description:
« Le principal levier de décarbonation du secteur, c’est le SAF », estime Antoine Jaeglé, de TotalEnergies aviation.
Le SAF, pour Sustainable Aviation Fuel ou carburant durable, est l’introduction d’une part de carburant réalisé à partir de biomolécules dans du kérosène traditionnel.
Le Béarn à la pointe « Le SAF représente les deux tiers de la solution de décarbonation de l’aérien à l’horizon 2050 », appuie Antoine Jaeglé.
La R & D de l’industriel œuvre à la construction de moteurs capables de faire voler des engins avec 100 % de biocarburants.
Le frein, c’est le coût car un litre de SAF revient deux fois plus cher qu’un litre de kérosène.
text:
« Le principal levier de décarbonation du secteur, c’est le SAF », estime Antoine Jaeglé, de TotalEnergies aviation. La filiale distribue 8 millions de tonnes de carburant sur 230 aéroports dans 50 pays. Le SAF, pour Sustainable Aviation Fuel ou carburant durable, est l’introduction d’une part de carburant réalisé à partir de biomolécules dans du kérosène traditionnel.

« Les biocarburants représentent les deux tiers de la solution de décarbonation de l’aérien à l’horizon 2050 »

Selon TotalEnergies, à peine 0,7 % de SAF est actuellement incorporé sur le marché alors que la réglementation européenne appelle à 10 % d’incorporation à l’horizon 2030. Et la « déclaration de Toulouse », en février 2022, engage 42 États, dont la France, à la neutralité carbone en 2050.

Le Béarn à la pointe

« Le SAF représente les deux tiers de la solution de décarbonation de l’aérien à l’horizon 2050 », appuie Antoine Jaeglé. Et le Béarn, comme la France, sont loin d’être en retard dans cet enjeu d’avenir de l’aviation. « Décarboner l’activité est notre priorité numéro 1 », affiche Nicolas Jeuland, de Safran. La R & D de l’industriel œuvre à la construction de moteurs capables de faire voler des engins avec 100 % de biocarburants.

Déjà, plusieurs de ses moteurs sont certifiés pour une intégration de 50 % de SAF et Nicolas Jeuland annonce le 100 % pour la fin de la décennie. Parallèlement, le bassin de Lacq s’apprête à accueillir la production de biocarburants pour avion avec le projet BioTjet porté par Elyse Energy. L’ambition est de produire du biokérozène à partir de biomasse composée de résidus issus majoritairement de la sylviculture locale et de déchets de bois en fin de vie. Il combine la production issue de biomasse avec l’injection d’hydrogène bas-carbone pour optimiser le rendement matière.

Du biocarburant à Lacq en 2030

« Nous allons déposer notre demande d’autorisation environnementale dans les jours à venir », a confié au salon GAD son cofondateur, Benoît Decourt, qui espère voir la production démarrer en 2030. Elyse Energy présentera d’ailleurs, ce vendredi, l’étude d’impacts sociaux économiques de son projet E-CHO à Pau. Pascal Clee, directeur du programme aviation chez le constructeur bigourdan Daher, souligne l’enjeu du prix des SAF dans leur développement.

L’avionneur consomme 400 000 litres de carburant par an dont 10 % de SAF depuis 2022 avec la volonté de participer à la décarbonation du ciel. « Techniquement, nous pourrions passer à 100 % de SAF sur nos activités. Le frein, c’est le coût car un litre de SAF revient deux fois plus cher qu’un litre de kérosène. » Dernier invité de la table ronde, l’universitaire Vincent Frigant pointe la cohérence et la stabilité des cadres réglementaires pour garantir un avenir à la filière.

title: Etihad's A380 Heads to Tokyo: Luxury Boost for UAE-Japan Flights in 2026 - Travel Radar
description:
Etihad Airways is set to launch its famous Airbus A380 on a new route from Abu Dhabi to Tokyo Narita beginning June 16, 2026.
The move follows the revival of a previously grounded A380 – number eight – to meet rising passenger needs across this busy route.
The decision to deploy the A380 to Tokyo highlights the strong customer interest in ease of travel between Abu Dhabi and Japan.
Inside the A380: What Travelers Can Expect Etihad’s A380 delivers top-tier travel in every cabin, built for ease during the nearly 10-hour trip.
Etihad’s big jet flying to Tokyo kicks off something fresh between UAE and Japan skies, more seats, top-notch comfort.
text:
Etihad Airways is set to launch its famous Airbus A380 on a new route from Abu Dhabi to Tokyo Narita beginning June 16, 2026. The move follows the revival of a previously grounded A380 – number eight – to meet rising passenger needs across this busy route. Instead of just economy seating, flyers now get everything Etihad’s high-end service offers: roomy cabins or even private living areas known as The Residence. With these upgrades, trips to Japan become way more comfortable and attractive for those crossing continents as well as connect the two economic hubs.

What’s pulling people to Tokyo?

The decision to deploy the A380 to Tokyo highlights the strong customer interest in ease of travel between Abu Dhabi and Japan.

As Arik De, Chief Revenue and Commercial Officer at Etihad Airways, noted:

“We’ve seen strong demand from customers for more seats to Japan, and the A380 allows us to deliver that. The aircraft is particularly well-suited to this route, given the importance of business travel between the UAE and Japan, two nations with deep economic and cultural ties.”

This step increases room while making Abu Dhabi a go-to pick for Japanese travelers checking out the UAE’s main city.

Since Japan keeps drawing both vacationers and professionals who fly with Etihad, launching this flight shows the carrier plans to stay active there for good.

Inside the A380: What Travelers Can Expect

Etihad’s A380 delivers top-tier travel in every cabin, built for ease during the nearly 10-hour trip.

First Class Apartments: Nine cozy cabins with fancy dish sets, plus a comfy leather seat turning into a full-size flat bed. Each comes with its own makeup area, while guests get special entry to a private wash space.

Business Studios: 70 personal spots upstairs, each near The Lobby – your go-to lounge with service and drinks when you need a break. Keep online using solid Wi-Fi coverage.

Economy Class: A cozy cabin offering 68 seats with added legroom – four inches wider or 337 Smart seats featuring adjustable headrests plus big cushions so you can relax easier.

The Residence: It is the top choice – three rooms maxed for two people, like a living space plus a sleep area, then your own washroom with a shower way up at 40K feet. Skip the menu – you pick what you want to eat; there’s bubbly, fancy fish eggs, maybe morning meals brought right to your bed, all handled by staff just for you.

Aviation fans or those after comfort, this design makes flying the best part of traveling. Whether you love planes or fancy perks, this plane makes soaring through air feels like checking into your hotel.

Route Details and Schedule

The A380 is flying every day, just right for busy summer trips. You can reserve seats today, adding to Etihad’s current big plane routes that hit London, Paris, then Toronto, also Singapore.

This timetable gives workers and holiday-goers smooth links, while leaving plenty of hours to check out both spots.

Etihad’s Tokyo expansion and broader impact for aviation © Etihad

Broader Impacts for Aviation

This A380 rollout reflects strong ties between the UAE and Japan, where extra seats may boost business trips along with commerce.

The hope seems to be that the flight upgrade can lift tourist numbers, convincing more travelers to Japan to make the stop over in Abu Dhabi while helping locals reach Tokyo easier.

Still, as airlines lean toward greener planes, doubts remain about using such a big jet on such a long flight, running a bigger engine is not cheap and this could put Etihad at a disadvantage versus rivals like Emirates or Qatar Airways across key Asia-Middle East routes. However, with rising tensions between Japan and China bringing a halt to popular Chinese airlines operating their routes to Japan, Etihad’s new route may be coming just at the right time to pick up a few passengers. You can find out more about the China – Japan situation here.

Even so, the choice strengthens Etihad’s position in top-tier international flights.

Etihad’s big jet flying to Tokyo kicks off something fresh between UAE and Japan skies, more seats, top-notch comfort. Still, some might wonder if huge planes fit today’s push for less fuel burn. Travelers gain more options across long distances.

title: Despite its advantages, Brazil still struggles to lure green industry - Valor International
description:
Even so, it continues to struggle to attract the “powershoring” investments sought by energy-intensive industries aiming to clean up their carbon footprint.
“It’s no use developing a green hydrogen project and installing a solar plant next to it; that won’t solve the problem.
Also at the event, State Grid Brazil CFO Chen Mingming said the country is the company’s most important market outside China.
For Pedrosa, the report reinforces that the energy transition is not simply an industrial strategy—it is a national project.
“Data centers, for example, require massive amounts of energy and water—and the Northeast faces water scarcity.
text:
Renowned worldwide for its leadership in renewable energy, Brazil now generates more electricity than it consumes. Even so, it continues to struggle to attract the “powershoring” investments sought by energy-intensive industries aiming to clean up their carbon footprint.

According to industry specialists, the country’s privileged position is also at risk. The Brazilian electricity sector faces mounting pressure from subsidies for renewable generation, which not only raise energy costs but also intensify the need for mandatory production cuts at existing plants—known in the sector as curtailments.

A survey by Volt Robotics shows that 5,900 GWh of wind and solar energy went ungenerated in October, equivalent to 37% of the capacity of these farms. Generator losses for the year have reached R$5.4 billion.

Despite this, Casa dos Ventos, Omnia, and Pátria announced earlier this month a R$50 billion data center project in Pecém (Ceará) to serve ByteDance, owner of TikTok. Other global tech giants—including Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon—have also been expanding investments in the country to meet their energy demand, drawn by its clean-energy potential. According to Brasscom, Brazil’s current data center capacity of roughly 800 megawatts could triple under Redata, the federal government’s incentive program launched in September.

The attraction goes beyond the surge in artificial intelligence. Entire sectors facing pressure to reduce their carbon footprint view Brazil as an opportunity to “green” their operations. The steel industry alone accounts for 7% to 9% of global greenhouse gas emissions, according to World Steel. Aluminum (2%), cement (7%-8%), and fertilizers (5%) are also among the energy-intensive sectors that could benefit. Emerging industries—green hydrogen, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and green methanol—could support the decarbonization of aviation and shipping, which account for 2.5% and 3% of global emissions, respectively.

Alongside abundant and affordable renewable energy, Brazil offers strategic advantages such as proximity to major consumer markets in the United States and Europe and distance from geopolitical conflict zones, experts note.

Still, the country’s surplus power comes mainly from new renewable sources—solar and wind—that run only part of the day, making it difficult to anchor highly energy-dependent industries, says Paulo Pedrosa, president of the Association of Large Industrial Energy Consumers and Free Consumers (Abrace).

“Powershoring is for heavy industry, which targets the global market. It requires massive investment—investment that only pays off if production runs 24 hours a day.”

There are ways to address this challenge, such as investing in energy storage systems. But battery technology remains relatively expensive, and debate continues over who should bear the cost—consumers or generators. It is one of the sector’s many unresolved issues.

Another bottleneck is geography. Most of Brazil’s solar and wind farms are located in the Northeast. In theory, industries could draw power from other regions when the sun isn’t shining or the wind isn’t blowing, but the national transmission system is not yet robust enough to support that.

“It’s no use developing a green hydrogen project and installing a solar plant next to it; that won’t solve the problem. You need access to the grid, because the sun goes down at 6 p.m., and operations cannot stop,” said João Carneiro, head of infrastructure at the IFC, the World Bank arm focused on private-sector lending. “Today, that capacity doesn’t exist. In our view, the four main green hydrogen projects planned for Pecém alone require 8 GW, but available capacity is between 1 and 3 GW,” added Carneiro, speaking at a powershoring seminar held in Fortaleza in October.

Also at the event, State Grid Brazil CFO Chen Mingming said the country is the company’s most important market outside China. State Grid is currently investing R$23 billion in a transmission line connecting the Northeast to the Central West, which will increase current capacity by 40%, from 13 GW.

“Northeast, please let the national grid be the battery of your powershoring strategy,” the executive said, addressing state officials, development banks, and business leaders.

Beyond expanding transmission capacity, the system must also offer redundancy, says infrastructure specialist and Inter.B partner Claudio Frischtak—ensuring that “if one line fails, another is available to guarantee supply.”

The transmission market is strong from a regulatory standpoint, and project acceleration is possible. But execution is slowed by broader national constraints, including a shortage of EPC contractors specializing in large-scale projects, he notes.

In his view, however, this is not the primary obstacle to powershoring. The central challenge is ensuring system stability—a task that will grow more complex as investments in distributed generation expand. To address this, he says, subsidies and incentives in the generation market must be reviewed.

“The alternative would be to invest in battery systems. But they don’t exist here because they’re expensive—and because the sector is addicted to subsidies. Why doesn’t the private sector offer batteries together with intermittent systems? Why does demand risk have to be transferred to the government when what we have is an excess of intermittent energy?” asks Frischtak.

“We need to stop digging the hole—stop increasing the supply of distributed generation,” adds Pedrosa of Abrace. “Yet last week, Congress approved Provisional Presidential Decree 1,304, which forces us to pay for more expensive sources, including coal. And there is still the possibility of approving PDL 365, which would revoke Aneel’s resolutions on the locational signal and reduce energy prices in the Northeast. It would be a complete demoralization of Aneel on the tariff front.”

A study by PwC for the industry association identified 30 industrial routes capable of adding R$1 trillion to GDP and generating more than 3 million jobs by 2030.

For Pedrosa, the report reinforces that the energy transition is not simply an industrial strategy—it is a national project. “This is what will generate jobs, tax revenue, and transformation at a scale far larger than any single sector. It breaks with our traditional model of setting quotas for specific products and forcing everyone to pay—driving up consumer costs. We need to rethink this logic and offer competitive prices, because the world will not buy expensive goods. We can produce goods that are both affordable and green.”

Industrial electricity prices in Brazil are slightly above the average observed among OECD members in 2023, according to Abrace and Aneel data. They are also higher than in countries such as the United States and South Korea. Still, Brazil benefits from a much cleaner power matrix—about 90% renewable—compared with 9.6% in South Korea and 24.1% in the United States, according to Ember. In Germany, a developed economy investing heavily in decarbonization, renewables account for 57.5%; in China, a global exporter of solar and wind technologies, the share is 33.6%.

Even so, Brazil must increase predictability and improve coordination to attract large-scale investment, says Maria Netto, executive president of the Climate and Society Institute (iCS).

“International investors naturally want to feel more comfortable about business-ecosystem conditions and alignment with national industrial policy,” she says. “Fertilizer makers, for example.”

“The traditional industry, which relies on minerals, could be very interested in coming to Brazil to produce fertilizers—taking advantage of renewable energy, supplying the local market, and becoming an exporter. But to make that move, companies need certainty: real demand and the infrastructure required to distribute what they produce.”

To help coordinate powershoring strategies, the iCS, the Northeast Consortium, and Banco do Nordeste do Brasil have launched a new forum.

“The region has ports and market access, but it doesn’t even have local transmission lines to move energy within its own borders. States often conduct studies and launch initiatives individually, or else remain dependent on the federal government. The region needs to look after itself—and understand that its potential is regional, not isolated,” she says.

For the president of Abrace, recent signals from the Executive Branch and from Senator Eduardo Braga, rapporteur of Provisional Presidential Decree 1,304, indicate that governments may finally be waking up to the issue.

“We need to take this debate out of the electricity sector—which is highly influenced by congressional lobbying—and move it into the country’s strategic agenda, where development and competitiveness come first. The private sector has also been very fragmented. The last provisional decree had drawbacks for consumers, but it also brought advances, such as improving price signals and curbing the growth of subsidies. And in the offshore wind bill, President Lula vetoed several items that would have made energy more expensive. So maybe we are at a turning point.”

Netto, from iCS, also argues that Brazil would benefit from prioritizing specific powershoring chains to build structural capacity. “Biomethanol for the maritime transport of green fertilizers, for example, is a chain that could serve Brazilian demand as well as international demand. Brazilian industries can participate; it doesn’t have to be only foreign players. These are win-win relationships.”

At the same time, she warns that not every initiative is realistic in the short term. “Data centers, for example, require massive amounts of energy and water—and the Northeast faces water scarcity. Could this create competition with local demand for energy and water? And if so, what social or technological compensation will exist?”

title: Unifor Meeting on Alberta's Energy Sector
description:
The Honourable Brian Jean Minister of Energy and Minerals, Government of Alberta Minister, Re: Unifor Meeting on Alberta’s Energy Sector On behalf of Unifor’s Energy Industry Council, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to meet on November 24 to discuss the priorities of our energy worker members.
Unifor Energy Council represents 15,000 members working in oil and gas extraction, natural gas distribution, electric utilities, and petroleum refineries across Canada.
Unifor is committed to an energy strategy that protects good, unionized jobs while ensuring a sustainable future for Alberta’s energy sector, specifically: Evolving regulations addressing methane leaks in the sector.
Unifor advocates for prioritizing Canadian (CANDU) technology that maximizes domestic economic benefits and ensures nuclear energy supply chain security.
Unifor supports the continued development of this sector through domestic content requirements, diversification of product including renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel, and countering U.S. subsidies.
text:
The Honourable Brian Jean

Minister of Energy and Minerals, Government of Alberta

Minister,

Re: Unifor Meeting on Alberta’s Energy Sector

On behalf of Unifor’s Energy Industry Council, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to meet on November 24 to discuss the priorities of our energy worker members. Unifor Energy Council represents 15,000 members working in oil and gas extraction, natural gas distribution, electric utilities, and petroleum refineries across Canada.

Unifor is committed to an energy strategy that protects good, unionized jobs while ensuring a sustainable future for Alberta’s energy sector, specifically:

Evolving regulations addressing methane leaks in the sector.

Supporting public procurement that supports a sovereign and secure nuclear supply chain.

Ensuring continued biofuels investment through domestic content requirements.

Expanding the use of existing rail infrastructure for the transport of energy products within Canada.

1. Keep it in the Pipe

Unifor’s Keep it in the Pipe campaign advocates for smart regulations to support investment in reducing methane emissions.

We are interested in continued engagement with the government through any working groups that examine best practices for leak detection and repair. This includes supporting the research and deployment of new leak detection technologies and ensuring regulations cover the entire supply chain of natural gas, including distribution.

2. Prioritizing CANDU technology

Unifor believes reliance on foreign developed and owned nuclear technology presents risks to energy sovereignty. Reliance on foreign-owned designs forces reliance on foreign intellectual property, supply chains, and enriched nuclear fuel imports. All of which are subject to U.S. export controls.

We caution against the current trend of expanding M.O.U.s for American-owned technology such as Small Modular Reactors by GE-Hitachi (BWRX-300) or Westinghouse large reactor development (AP-1000).

Unifor advocates for prioritizing Canadian (CANDU) technology that maximizes domestic economic benefits and ensures nuclear energy supply chain security.

3. Biofuel domestic content and investment

Alberta are home to key biofuel facilities, however the industry faces an existential threat from subsidized American imports.

Unifor supports the continued development of this sector through domestic content requirements, diversification of product including renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel, and countering U.S. subsidies.

4. The transport of oil and energy product

Unifor supports the continued commercial investment and maintenance of pipelines if they also meet the needs of workers and the communities and environment they pass through.

However, we believe Canadian oil and gas should be refined and transported from extraction to regions where Canadian industry needs oil and chemical inputs without that product travelling through other countries.

To fill the immediate demand for these products across Canada, Unifor also supports the transporting of oil and chemical product east, west, and north by rail.

Unifor looks forward to continuing this dialogue to build Alberta’s energy strategy.

Sincerely,

description:
Key Takeaways: Oppenheimer's upcoming virtual meeting will spotlight GEVO (GEVO, Financial), offering insights into its market potential.
Gevo Inc operates in the renewable chemicals and biofuels sector, focusing on alternatives to petroleum-based products.
Despite revenue growth, Gevo faces financial challenges, including negative margins and insider selling activity.
One of the stocks to be highlighted in this session is GEVO (GEVO), where investors can expect an in-depth discussion on its potential and market performance.
The upcoming Oppenheimer meeting may provide further insights into the company's strategic direction and market potential.
text:
Key Takeaways:

Oppenheimer's upcoming virtual meeting will spotlight GEVO (GEVO, Financial), offering insights into its market potential.

Gevo Inc operates in the renewable chemicals and biofuels sector, focusing on alternatives to petroleum-based products.

Despite revenue growth, Gevo faces financial challenges, including negative margins and insider selling activity.

Oppenheimer is set to host a virtual meeting on December 2 at 10 a.m. This event will focus on discussing key insights and strategies pertinent to the market. One of the stocks to be highlighted in this session is GEVO (GEVO), where investors can expect an in-depth discussion on its potential and market performance.

Gevo Inc is a renewable chemicals and biofuels company engaged in the development and commercialization of alternatives to petroleum-based products based on isobutanol produced from renewable feedstocks. The company operates through segments such as Gevo, GevoFuels, and GevoRNG, with a focus on sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and other renewable hydrocarbons. Gevo Inc is positioned within the Basic Materials sector, specifically in the Chemicals industry, with a market capitalization of $508.85 million.

Financial Health Analysis

Gevo Inc has demonstrated significant revenue growth, with a 3-year revenue growth rate of 189.8%. However, the company's profitability metrics reveal challenges:

Operating Margin: -23.34%

Net Margin: -37.33%

Gross Margin: 46.71%

Gevo's balance sheet shows a current ratio of 1.91 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.36, indicating moderate leverage. However, warning signs include an Altman Z-Score of -0.1, suggesting financial distress, and significant insider selling activity, with 13 transactions in the past three months.

Valuation & Market Sentiment

Gevo's valuation metrics reflect its current market position:

Price-to-Sales Ratio: 4.05

Price-to-Book Ratio: 1.08

Analyst sentiment is mixed, with a recommendation score of 2.5 and a target price of $5.44. Technical indicators such as the RSI of 50.33 suggest a neutral market sentiment. Institutional ownership stands at 31.76%, with insider ownership at 5.5%.

Risk Assessment

Gevo's financial health is categorized as distressed, with a GF Score of 64, indicating potential value traps. The company's volatility is high at 69.36, and its beta of 1.12 suggests above-average market risk. Sector-specific risks include regulatory changes in renewable energy and competition from established petroleum-based products.

In conclusion, while Gevo Inc presents growth opportunities in the renewable energy sector, investors should be cautious of its financial challenges and market volatility. The upcoming Oppenheimer meeting may provide further insights into the company's strategic direction and market potential.

title: Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics Seal Long-Term SAF Agreement to Advance ...
description:
Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have turned their summer Memorandum of Understanding on sustainable aviation fuel into a binding agreement.
The deal was signed on November 21 during CEVA Logistics’ Airfreight Annual Strategic Partners Council in Paris.
For Lufthansa Cargo, the agreement reinforces its close cooperation with CEVA, especially on future-focused topics such as sustainability.
“CEVA Logistics’ decision to scale up its use of SAF reflects a clear commitment to advancing the decarbonisation of air freight.
The agreement strengthens their joint effort to deliver verifiable CO₂ reduction and deepen cooperation on sustainable logistics.
text:
Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have turned their summer Memorandum of Understanding on sustainable aviation fuel into a binding agreement. The deal was signed on November 21 during CEVA Logistics’ Airfreight Annual Strategic Partners Council in Paris. CEVA has committed to using SAF credits in 2025, representing an emissions reduction of 8,000 tonnes of CO₂.

The MoU has now been formalised into a long-term framework agreement that runs through 2028. Both companies describe it as the result of a long-standing relationship built on transparency, steady collaboration and shared learning. “This agreement marks an important step in our sustainable partnership with Lufthansa Cargo. It allows us to cut emissions in a measurable way and strengthen the sustainability of our supply chains, supported by a partner committed to transparency, strong standards and credible certification,” said Loïc Gay, Global Air & Ocean Products VP at CEVA Logistics.

For Lufthansa Cargo, the agreement reinforces its close cooperation with CEVA, especially on future-focused topics such as sustainability. “CEVA Logistics’ decision to scale up its use of SAF reflects a clear commitment to advancing the decarbonisation of air freight. Protecting the climate depends on strong partnerships and determined action, and this agreement gives us a solid base to move forward together,” said Anand Kulkarni, Head of Global Markets.

The framework also sets out how both sides will continue to collaborate on SAF and plan additional measures over time. The fuel used is produced only from waste and residual materials, contains no palm oil and meets leading international sustainability standards. Emission reductions will be validated for CEVA through audited mitigation certificates, supported by Lufthansa Cargo’s certified Proof of Sustainability process. The agreement strengthens their joint effort to deliver verifiable CO₂ reduction and deepen cooperation on sustainable logistics.

This SAF commitment builds on a wider sustainability partnership between the two companies, including shared expertise, circular economy initiatives and joint innovation and research projects.

title: Star Air eyes first direct Embraer order as it targets 50 aircraft by 2030
description:
The carrier began operations in January 2019 and has grown during the pandemic, leveraging India’s UDAN government subsidy program.
Star Air aims to increase its fleet to 50 aircraft by 2030, supporting a network that now includes 31 cities.
Embraer has not yet secured an order from Indian airlines, a situation that Star Air could also take advantage of.
Star Air recently completed the first tranche of a funding round.
Star Air plans to operate 20 aircraft by April 2028, which would enable the launch of international flights under these new provisions.
text:
Star Air, currently India’s largest regional airline, is considering a substantial Embraer aircraft order for next year as it looks to expand its operations beyond its present fleet of 11 aircraft, all from the Brazilian manufacturer.

The carrier began operations in January 2019 and has grown during the pandemic, leveraging India’s UDAN government subsidy program. Star Air aims to increase its fleet to 50 aircraft by 2030, supporting a network that now includes 31 cities.

“In our fleet current, four aircraft are owned and the rest are leased,” said Managing Director Shrenik Ghodawat, from the Sanjay Ghodawat Group, parent company of the airline, to The Times of India.

Follow us: WhatsApp | BlueSky | Google News | Instagram | LinkedIn | Facebook

According to Ghodawat, the airline operates 56 daily flights, with 65% of these falling under the UDAN scheme. “Today we have 56 daily flights, with 65% being UDAN, in our network of 31 cities,” he said.

The Bengaluru-based carrier has four 50-seat ERJ-145s and seven E175s. These jets began arriving on lease in 2023 in a two-class configuration (12+64), but in 2025 four aircraft with 88 seats in a single class were received.

However, Ghodawat did not specify which aircraft are being evaluated at Embraer. Besides the already operated E175s, other alternatives include the E190-E2 for approximately 110 passengers, and the E195-E2, with up to 146 seats.

The E2 models, however, are more expensive, although they offer a lower operating cost per seat. Embraer has not yet secured an order from Indian airlines, a situation that Star Air could also take advantage of.

Star Air recently completed the first tranche of a funding round. The company has outlined plans to develop proprietary facilities for maintenance, repair, and crew training to support its growth trajectory.

The Indian government has indicated intentions to extend the UDAN scheme to nearby international routes. Star Air plans to operate 20 aircraft by April 2028, which would enable the launch of international flights under these new provisions.

title: Thirty Eighth Report - Delegated Powers and Regulatory Reform Committee - Parliament UK
description:
4.The Department for Transport has provided a Delegated Powers Memorandum (“the Memorandum”) explaining and justifying the Bill’s delegated powers.
The Bill includes twelve delegated powers two of which, in clauses 1(8) and 11(4)(a), are Henry VIII powers.
5.This note draws the House’s attention to one delegated power.
Clause 11(4)(b)–determination of turnover 6.The Bill confers delegated powers to raise and dispose of levy funding.
The approach taken by the Government to clause 11(4)(a) accords with this principle.
text:
Thirty Eighth Report Contents

Thirty Eighth Report

Sustainable Aviation Fuel Bill

1. The Sustainable Aviation Fuel Bill was brought to the House of Lords on 20 October 2025. Second reading was on 20 November and Committee Stage is scheduled to begin on 10 December.

2.Sustainable Aviation Fuel (“SAF”) is a lower carbon aviation fuel and the Government considers its use to be “one of the most effective ways to reduce aviation emissions right now”. However, in the Government’s view a number of risks discourage investment and hinder the development of a market in SAF production. One of these perceived risks is revenue uncertainty risk.

3.The Bill is intended to establish a revenue certainty mechanism to support SAF production and long-term investment in the United Kingdom. The Bill will enable the Secretary of State to designate a contractual counterparty, wholly owned by Government, and direct it to enter into contracts with producers that guarantee a price for their SAF over a set period; under the contracts the counterparty will pay producers the difference between the market price and a guaranteed “strike price” (if the strike price is higher) or receive the difference from the producer (if the strike price if lower). A levy on suppliers of aviation fuel will fund the mechanism and its administration.

4.The Department for Transport has provided a Delegated Powers Memorandum (“the Memorandum”) explaining and justifying the Bill’s delegated powers. The Bill includes twelve delegated powers two of which, in clauses 1(8) and 11(4)(a), are Henry VIII powers. Both of these appear to be justified and comply with our frequently cited presumption that such powers should be subject to affirmative procedure unless there is compelling justification to the contrary. However we are disappointed that the Memorandum does not acknowledge that the Bill includes Henry VIII powers. Our Guidance for Departments requires that such powers are clearly identified.

5.This note draws the House’s attention to one delegated power.

Clause 11(4)(b)–determination of turnover

6.The Bill confers delegated powers to raise and dispose of levy funding. Exercise of these powers will necessarily involve imposing statutory duties on suppliers of aviation fuel. Clause 11(1) confers a power on the Secretary of State to enforce these duties by imposing a financial penalty on suppliers who are in breach. The maximum amount of the penalty appears on the face of the Bill in clause 11(3) as the lesser of:

£100,000, and

an amount equal to 10% of turnover of the person on whom it is imposed.

7.Clause 11(4) is a delegated power that allows regulations to be made:

(a)amending the figure of £100, 000 in the light of inflation, and

(b)setting out how turnover is to be determined.

8.Regulations exercising the power in (a) are subject to affirmative provision and those exercising the power in (b) are subject to negative procedure.

9.We have consistently taken the view that the maximum amount of any financial penalty should be set out on the face of a Bill with, where necessary, a delegated power subject to affirmative procedure to vary that amount. The approach taken by the Government to clause 11(4)(a) accords with this principle.

10.It also seems reasonable in our view for the Government to seek the delegated power in clause 11(4)(b) to set out how turnover is to be determined since doing so is likely to involve technical detail and will involve judgments about fair treatment of those subject to the levy. However, clause 11(4)(b) is of at least equal significance to 11(4)(a) in setting the maximum amount of any financial penalty so it appears to us inconsistent that its exercise is subject to negative procedure.

11.In our report on the Online Safety Bill, we discussed a power to set the definition of “qualifying worldwide revenue” which term was used in that Bill as “turnover” is in this: to partially determine the maximum level of financial penalty for breach of statutory duty. We concluded, noting precedent in the Product Security and Telecommunications Infrastructure Act 2022, that the definition should be set in regulations subject to affirmative procedure because it went to the “highly significant matter of the level of financial penalties”. The close similarity to setting out how turnover is to be determined in setting a maximum financial penalty is in our view clear.

12.The Memorandum does not seek to justify the use of negative procedure for exercise of the power in clause 11(4)(b). It is concerning that instead it wrongly suggests that the power to set how turnover is determined is subject to affirmative procedure.

title: Bell 505 achieves over 700 flight hours with blended SAF : The Daily Digest
description:
In Germany, Bell Textron announced that a single, dedicated Bell 505 has surpassed 700 flight hours using blended sustainable aviation fuel.
In March 2022, Bell announced its collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines to explore technical performance and economic impacts of sustainable aviation fuel on the Bell 505 powered by the Arrius 2R engine.
Nearly one year after the announcement, the Bell 505 became the first-ever single engine helicopter to fly with 100% SAF during a demonstration flight, the firm said.
Since July 2022, Bell has accumulated over 700 flight hours using blended SAF on a single Bell 505 helicopter at the Bell Training Academy.
Assessments of engine operability and aircraft performance as well as engine inspections have yielded positive results to date, the company added.
text:
In Germany, Bell Textron announced that a single, dedicated Bell 505 has surpassed 700 flight hours using blended sustainable aviation fuel.

In March 2022, Bell announced its collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines to explore technical performance and economic impacts of sustainable aviation fuel on the Bell 505 powered by the Arrius 2R engine. Nearly one year after the announcement, the Bell 505 became the first-ever single engine helicopter to fly with 100% SAF during a demonstration flight, the firm said.

Since July 2022, Bell has accumulated over 700 flight hours using blended SAF on a single Bell 505 helicopter at the Bell Training Academy. Assessments of engine operability and aircraft performance as well as engine inspections have yielded positive results to date, the company added.

title: Partnership between Vibra Energia and the government of Bahia: Salvador Airport ...
description:
O uso do SAF é considerado hoje a forma mais rápida e prática de reduzir as emissões da aviação comercial.
Operação diária no Aeroporto de Salvador com combustível sustentável A operação inaugurada no Aeroporto de Salvador não se limita a voos simbólicos ou experimentais.
A companhia também avança em negociações para expandir a oferta de SAF para outros estados e aeroportos.
Impactos ambientais do combustível sustentável (SAF) O impacto ambiental do SAF é a principal razão para sua adoção global.
Com a operação já em curso, outros aeroportos podem observar o modelo adotado em Salvador para replicá-lo em suas estruturas.
text:
O Aeroporto de Salvador inicia abastecimento regular com combustível sustentável da Vibra Energia, marcando um avanço no uso de SAF no Brasil e impulsionando a aviação de baixo carbono com ganhos ambientais significativos

On November 26th, 2025, Salvador International Airport tornou-se o primeiro do Brasil a abastecer voos comerciais com sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) provided by Vibra Energy. A operação inaugural representa um marco inédito para a aviação brasileira e um avanço significativo na agenda de decarbonization of air transport. A iniciativa envolve rotas regulares operadas com uma mistura de 10% de SAF e 90% de querosene tradicional, já sendo aplicada nos voos diários para Brasília e São Paulo.

Por que o SAF representa um avanço imediato para o Brasil

De acordo com as informações divulgadas pela empresa e pelo governo da Bahia, o uso do combustível sustentável pode reduzir até 80% of greenhouse gas emissions ao longo do ciclo de vida do produto. Além disso, a prestação desse serviço coloca Salvador como referência nacional ao se tornar o primeiro aeroporto brasileiro a ter um fornecimento constante de SAF para voos comerciais.

O uso do SAF é considerado hoje a forma mais rápida e prática de reduzir as emissões da aviação comercial. Isso ocorre porque o combustível sustentável pode ser utilizado em aeronaves convencionais sem exigir qualquer modificação técnica ou substituição de infraestrutura aeroportuária. Esse aspecto torna o combustível um aliado estratégico para acelerar a transição energética do setor aéreo.

O SAF fornecido pela Vibra Energy é produzido a partir de resíduos renováveis, como óleos usados, gorduras residuais e restos da agroindústria. Por utilizar materiais de baixo impacto ambiental, o ciclo de vida do produto emite menos carbono, o que resulta na redução significativa de gases de efeito estufa ao ser comparado ao querosene fóssil.

A certificação internacional aplicada ao combustível assegura rastreabilidade e comprovação de sustentabilidade. Isso significa que a origem da matéria-prima, o processo de produção e o transporte são verificados por entidades independentes, garantindo credibilidade aos resultados ambientais apresentados.

Operação diária no Aeroporto de Salvador com combustível sustentável

A operação inaugurada no Aeroporto de Salvador não se limita a voos simbólicos ou experimentais. Em vez disso, estabelece um padrão diário, com dois voos abastecidos regularmente com a mistura de 10% de SAF. Essa constância demonstra que o mercado brasileiro está preparado para integrar o combustível sustentável à rotina operacional da aviação.

O fornecimento inicial previsto para a fase de implementação chega a alguns milhões de litros, destinados exclusivamente para as rotas que partem da capital baiana. Isso demonstra que há planejamento de longo prazo, e não apenas projetos pontuais.

A Vibra Energy, que é responsável por abastecer mais de 90 aeroportos no país, estruturou sua cadeia logística para garantir o fornecimento contínuo do combustível sustentável. Como a empresa foi a primeira a disponibilizar SAF comercialmente no Brasil, Salvador se tornou o local ideal para iniciar a operação regular.

A companhia também avança em negociações para expandir a oferta de SAF para outros estados e aeroportos. Caso esse processo evolua, Salvador pode se transformar em um polo nacional de abastecimento sustentável, incentivando a expansão da aviação verde no país.

Impactos ambientais do combustível sustentável (SAF)

O impacto ambiental do SAF é a principal razão para sua adoção global. Mesmo com apenas 10% de mistura, há uma redução perceptível nas emissões de carbono. Quando utilizado em proporções maiores — o que é tecnicamente possível — o benefício se torna ainda mais expressivo, aproximando a aviação das metas globais estabelecidas por organismos internacionais.

Estudos indicam que o combustível sustentável pode reduzir até 80% das emissões de CO₂, dependendo da matéria-prima utilizada no processo produtivo. Essa redução considera todo o ciclo de vida do produto, desde a produção até a queima nos motores.

Para Salvador, a operação cria oportunidades de desenvolvimento econômico e ambiental. A cidade já é reconhecida como um polo turístico e logístico, e agora reforça o seu papel estratégico em iniciativas de inovação e sustentabilidade.

Para o Brasil, a iniciativa representa um avanço alinhado às metas de redução de emissões assumidas internacionalmente. A aviação é um setor conhecido por sua dificuldade de descarbonização, e o SAF desponta como a alternativa mais eficaz no curto e médio prazo.

Aeroporto de Salvador como referência nacional em aviação sustentável

Ao inaugurar essa operação, o Aeroporto Internacional de Salvador se posiciona como pioneiro no país e reforça sua relevância no cenário nacional. A iniciativa soma-se a projetos que já vinham sendo implementados no terminal, incluindo sistemas de eficiência energética, modernização da infraestrutura e práticas sustentáveis de gestão.

Ser o primeiro aeroporto brasileiro a oferecer abastecimento regular com combustível sustentável é mais do que um título simbólico — é um reconhecimento da capacidade técnica, da articulação institucional e do compromisso com a agenda climática.

Com a operação já em curso, outros aeroportos podem observar o modelo adotado em Salvador para replicá-lo em suas estruturas. A experiência prática facilitará a elaboração de políticas públicas, ajustes regulatórios e incentivos fiscais que favoreçam o uso do SAF em todo o país.

À medida que a oferta e a demanda crescem, o custo tende a diminuir, tornando o combustível sustentável mais competitivo e ampliando seu uso no setor aéreo.

Desafios para o avanço do SAF no país

Apesar dos benefícios ambientais, a ampliação do uso do SAF enfrenta desafios. O principal deles é o custo de produção, que ainda é superior ao do querosene convencional. Como o mercado brasileiro está em fase inicial, o volume disponível também é limitado.

Outro ponto relevante é a necessidade de políticas públicas específicas, capazes de estimular a produção nacional e reduzir a dependência de importações. Incentivos tributários, financiamentos e parcerias entre empresas e governos são fundamentais para impulsionar a cadeia produtiva.

A operação em Salvador, contudo, mostra que mesmo com os desafios, é possível estruturar um modelo viável e tecnicamente seguro.

A relevância do uso de SAF para o futuro da aviação brasileira

A operação iniciada no Aeroporto Internacional de Salvador representa um marco decisivo para o setor aéreo. O uso do SAF fornece benefícios ambientais comprovados, reforça a competitividade do país no cenário internacional e demonstra que a transição energética na aviação já está em andamento.

Ao adotar o combustível sustentável de forma regular, Salvador estabelece uma referência para todo o território nacional. A iniciativa demonstra que a inovação ambiental pode caminhar ao lado da operação comercial, mantendo a segurança, a eficiência e a regularidade dos voos.

The advance of Vibra Energy como fornecedora do SAF reforça o protagonismo nacional na distribuição de combustíveis mais limpos, abrindo caminho para que outras empresas ampliem seus investimentos.
